title: A Young Mother Shares Her Inspiring Personal Story...
content: Eight months ago, I wouldnt have thought that I would feel so engaged in my life again. I knew something was off but no one understood. Doctors told me that I was pre-menopausal (that did not go over well), I had post partum depression (my baby is 7 years old), or there was nothing wrong with me this is who I am. I couldnt accept these answers. I knew that I was a happy person, I loved to laugh, and I could keep up with my children and find success in my career. Where had that person gone? I was now completely apathetic to my family and marriage; I couldnt make it through the day without a nap, yet couldnt sleep at night; irritated at everything and everyone; no focus; no drive professionally or personally and on top of that I was gaining weight! There had to be more than just my to-do list. Fake it til you feel it was my daily mantra.Thankfully, I have great friends with whom I feel comfortable sharing the good, bad and the ugly. They listened and I realized that I wasnt alone. One had struggled with a lot of the same feelings and told me about Dr. Tutera and SottoPelle. I went home, did my research on hormone replacement therapy and the next morning called and made an appointment with Dr. Gino Tutera. During my appointment, Dr. Tutera reviewed my blood work, explaining to me what my hormone levels were and what they meant affirming that indeed, all of these feelings of fatigue, irritation, weight gain, etc. were all directly related to my hormone levels. He gave me hope! Within 48 hours, I began feeling better, more in control. Each day since, I feel more like myself again. My husband and children have each acknowledged this change. Our home is a happier place we have fun together. I am grateful to Dr. Tutera for his dedication, support to womens (&amp;amp; mens) health and the personal attention he provides to each patient. I have found the joy in my life again! Thank you Dr. T!Melissa CarterSatisfied SottoPelle Patient&lt;em id=&quot;__mceDel&quot;&gt;April 16, 2013&lt;/em&gt;&lt;div style=&quot;max-width: 460px; float: center; width: 460px; padding: 10px;&quot;&gt;http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KUAfH5cWLUo&lt;/div&gt;

title: A Mother's Day Message of Hope: Hormonal Imbalance Often Misdiagnosed for Depression
content: &lt;p style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;/p&gt;Mothers Day is a day to celebrate the woman, the mother who unselfishly gives of herself to those she loves. But often times for many moms, taking on and functioning each day is a struggle. For women who experience feelings of being less than desirable, lack energy, overly irritable at the slightest annoyance, many doctors might conclude: It seems you may be suffering from depression. The quick solution for these doctors is often to prescribe any number of anti-depressants whose side effects may cause additional symptoms such as weight gain, decrease in energy, reduced libido and/or a lack of motivation. In many ways, those patients may feel worse than when they first saw their doctor!Many physicians hear and see the obvious yet tend to address the &quot;tip of the iceberg.&quot; Some may not take the time to assess the whole patient from the inside out, and be quick to write a prescription. Only to regress to the mentality of &quot;take two of these and call me in the morning&quot; approach. In most cases the patients complaints to their physicians go unheeded or ignored. This often causes great anxiety and depression as well.What these physicians fail to examine is the impact hormones play in the equation. Physicians are quick to put a Band-Aid on what they believe is the symptom, rather than taking the time to look at all the factors that make up the patient and the cause as to why the patient isfeelingthe way they do. The symptoms of&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.ajog.org/article/0002-9378%2895%2990297-X/abstract&quot;&gt;depression mentioned above can be caused by hormonal imbalance.&lt;/a&gt;An experienced physician will not only request a patient to get their blood work done, but more importantly, a qualified and knowledgeable physician will know how to read your blood lab results. A patient whose lab work indicated normal levels but is unaware that the caregiver has not measured the regulatory hormone, has been done a great disservice. As patients, they have the feeling something is wrong, but when they hear that &quot;everything is normal&quot; and, therefore, &quot;its all in your head,&quot; they cant help but feel frustrated and helpless.Without proper blood work and a seasoned physician to translate the results, an accurate diagnosis may never be realized. Numerous women who suffer from hormonal imbalance are often treated for the wrong diagnosis. These patients often become discouraged whentheircondition worsens and often times spiral into a deeper depression.The proper&lt;a href=&quot;/?page_id=262&quot;&gt;Hormone replacement&lt;/a&gt; improves energy levels and overall mood without the need for psychotropic drugs. As women reach menopause, the change in hormones, particularly the drop in estrogen levels,causes the body to handle stress less effectively. As stress increases, hormone levels may become even more out of balance and amplify stress, which can lead to depression. Adecreased production of testosterone in women may also cause mental fogginess, decrease in energy and libido and patients often become depressed due to their unwanted negativephysical and mental symptoms.Being a mom and taking care of thefamilyis difficult enough without struggling through the day withfeelings ofdepression. As we approach Mothers Day, many moms willreceiveheart-felt gifts from their children and spouses. We hope that all women realize, whether they are a mother or not, that the best gift they can give themselvesis the gift of health. At SottoPelle Therapy, we are committed to enriching lives by providing ourscientificallyproven methodology in treating hormonal imbalance. For the many women and &quot;moms&quot; who have inspired us to continue our work, we want to wish you a Happy Mothers Day. Your inspiring stories of how SottoPelle has changed your lives is what keeps us going.&lt;a href=&quot;/?page_id=39&quot;&gt;Dr. Gino Tutera&lt;/a&gt;, a leading authority in hormone replacement, says men and women report the following positive results after beginning hormone replacement therapy withSottoPelle Therapy: Feel much more in control of their bodies and their lives Sleep more consistently and soundly Have more interest in sex Enjoy renewed vitality and zest Realize greater mental clarity Feel more enthusiasm for life Feel calmer, relaxed and more even-keeledThe direct results of proper hormonal treatment helps with the feelings of depression. If your doctor diagnoses you with depression, be sure and ask that your hormone levels be tested and ask them if hormone imbalance might be the cause of your symptoms. If your regular doctor does not share the same drive to find whats ailing you, then its time to find a qualified physician who specializes in hormone replacement such as those trained by Dr Tutera &amp;amp; SottoPelle. No one knows better what your &quot;old self&quot; used to be like but you. With the right medical team on your side, they will help you find the &quot;true&quot; you again.&lt;a href=&quot;/?page_id=39&quot;&gt;&lt;i&gt;Dr. Gino Tutera&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;i&gt; is a pioneer and leader in the field of &lt;/i&gt;&lt;a title=&quot;Bio-Identical Hormones&quot; href=&quot;/?page_id=268&quot;&gt;&lt;i&gt;bio-identical hormone&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;i&gt; replacement therapy. As a board certified OB/GYN, he has dedicated more than thirty years of his medical career to the clinical study, science and treatment of hormonal imbalance. In 2002, Dr. Tutera founded &lt;/i&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.sottopelletherapy.com/&quot;&gt;&lt;i&gt;SottoPelle Therapy&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;i&gt;and has since been invited to speak at international medical conventions in front of thousands of fellow physicians. title: BALANCED HORMONES: Healthy Aging Depends on Balance
content: &lt;p align=&quot;center&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;HISTORY AND HYSTERIA&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Throughout history, healers, high priests, physicians,scientists and others have persistently worked to discover and understand the mysterious workings of the human body. Its astonishing to think that the study of physiology actually predates recorded history, even though much of what was believed in those ancient times was couched in magic, superstition and ritual. All the same, sophisticated medical techniques were employed thousands of years before Hippocrates became the father of modern medicine. There is a record; in fact, of Egyptian priest-physicians preforming cancer surgeries as far back as 3000 B.C.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; The human body is an incredibly complex marvel and continues to baffle us in many ways. It remains something of a frontier in spite of significant progress. Nevertheless, as we look at the average human lifespan, which in classical Greece is thought to have been around 28 years and today ranges between 70 and 80-plus years in Western counties, its obvious how far weve come.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; But, as the saying goes,&lt;i&gt;what a long, strange trip its been!&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; One experience that has remained sadly true though time, regardless of our highly evolved scientific body of knowledge: in most of the worlds cultures, a woman suffering from hormone-related problems continues to be the target of superstition, intolerance and misunderstanding.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; For many, many centuries, menstruating women were shunned and considered&lt;i&gt;impure&lt;/i&gt;. Menopausewas likewise seen as shameful. A woman was thought to have outlived her usefulness if she could no longer bear children. Around 1700 and thereafter, menopause began to be viewed as a&lt;i&gt;disease&lt;/i&gt;something that lingers even today. Women were often subjected to grotesque methods of treatment that included dangerous or life-threatening surgeries in order to cure them. The Victorian era brought with it the idea that womens physical constitution predisposed her to insanity. The womb and brain were said to have a direct relationship- one that sent many symptomatic woman to the asylum as a&lt;i&gt;remedy&lt;/i&gt;for her hysteria.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; Seems pretty archaic, doesnt it? To this day, women still remain subject to outdated attitudes and treatment methods for their hormone woes, not to mention out-and-out deceptions. If not being sold a bill of goods on the safety of synthetics and lack of data on bio-identicals by the pharmaceutical industry, then its the conventional medical community encouraging women to be fearful of their own hormonesvital contributors to a persons well-being and the foundation for the healthiest and most vibrant years of life! No wonder so many women continue to be utterly bewildered by hormone replacement choices.&lt;/div&gt;

title: The Need For Healthy Hormone Levels Never Goes Away
content: &lt;div&gt;&lt;p align=&quot;center&quot;&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p align=&quot;center&quot;&gt;Lets move beyond hysteria for the moment and look at the verifiable science surrounding hormonal imbalance, menopause and aging.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;div&gt; Its a fact thatnormal&lt;a title=&quot;What is Hormone Replacement Therapy?&quot; href=&quot;/?page_id=260&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;hormone levels&lt;/a&gt;(meaning whats normal for each individual) equate to the vitality and peak performance of youth. In your twenties and thirties, the bodys ability to maintain homeostasis defines you physically, mentally and emotionally, and helps protect you from a myriad of diseases. On the reverse side, the process of aging markedly decreases the production of endocrine hormones and increases your vulnerability to cardiovascular disease, arthritis, osteoporosis, cancer, diabetes and other long-term, degenerative diseases.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; A synergetic relationship exists between every process, every hormone and every organ, gland and cell in the body. Disrupt any of it, especially the production of hormones, weather through the aging process, genetic predisposition, illness or surgical procedure, and physiologic disruption ensures, which in turn creates an inviting environment for health problems.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; Ill use thetestosteroneas an example. Research has shown that human testosterone has many important functions in addition to enhancing the libido. It augments bone strength, density and the ability of bone to repair itself. Testosterone also improves mood and heightens the feeling of well-being; increases muscle strength and mass; thickens the skin; promotes optimal brain function and more.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; If testosterone produces all of these beneficial effects, it only makes sense that when it diminishes significantly, as it does in the aging male and female, the health and welfare of the individual also weakens. There is now a great deal of medical literature supporting this conclusion, with many new research studies underway. Current literature already corroborates that low levels of testosterone are directly linked to:&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Osteoporosisand hip fracture&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Heart diseaseand myocardial infraction&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Strokes and cardiovascular disease&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Prostate cancer (&lt;i&gt;indeed, low levels create higher risk&lt;/i&gt;)&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;Senile dementia&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;A recent study published in&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.j-alz.com%2fpress%2f2010%2f20100215.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;2010 in theJournal of Alzheimers Disease&lt;/a&gt;has additionally linked low testosterone in older men to Alzheimers disease. Still, there are many mainstream medical professionals who question these results and refuse to believe in the therapeutic value of maintaining normal testosterone levels in aging men and women. Low testosterone is not considered a life-threatening problem and many physicians simply do not know how to diagnose or treat it.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;a title=&quot;Hormone Replacement Therapy for Women&quot; href=&quot;/?page_id=262&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Estrogen&lt;/a&gt;is another case in point.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; Fact #1: Estrogen helps maintain healthy blood vessels and provides protection from heart attacks and strokes.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; Fact #2:&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.heart.org/HEARTORG/Advocate/IssuesandCampaigns/QualityCare/Women-and-Heart-Disease_UCM_430484_Article.jsp&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Heart disease is the leading cause of death in women over the age of 75.&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; &lt;a title=&quot;Hormone Replacement Therapy for Women&quot; href=&quot;/?page_id=262&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Women&lt;/a&gt; commonly have a low risk for cardiovascular disease until menopause, around age 50, when their estrogen levels plummet and the ratio of estradiol to estrone goes haywire. Menopause and estrogen imbalance are also associated with osteoporosis, breast cancer and other serious health issues.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; Estrogen, in proper balance, is your friend!&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;div&gt; Research indicates that, besides heart and artery protection, estrogen protects against cognitive decline during aging and perhaps even against Alzheimers disease. Studies of post-mortem brains of women with Alzheimers disease, reported in the online edition of the&lt;i&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.pnas.org/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/i&gt;in 2005, showed they had significantlylower levels of estrogen in their brain tissue as compared to women of similar age without the disorder.&amp;nbsp;Excerpt from The Science of SottoPelle, written by Gino Tutera MD, FACOG&lt;i&gt;&lt;/i&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;i&gt;&lt;a title=&quot;Gino Tutera MD FACOG&quot; href=&quot;/?page_id=39&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Dr. Gino Tutera&lt;/a&gt;is a pioneer and leader in the field of&lt;a title=&quot;Bio-Identical Hormones&quot; href=&quot;/?page_id=268&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;bio-identical hormone&lt;/a&gt;replacement therapy. As a board certified OB/GYN, he has dedicated more than thirty years of his medical career to the clinical study, science and treatment of hormonal imbalance. In 2002, Dr. Tutera founded&lt;a title=&quot;Our Method&quot; href=&quot;/?page_id=42&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;SottoPelle Therapy&lt;/a&gt;and has since been invited to speak at international medical conventions in front of thousands of fellow physicians. Dr. Tutera has authored three books on the world-renowned methodology of SottoPelle Therapy. His&lt;/i&gt;&lt;i&gt;His books are sold individually in Spanish and inEnglish in print format or you can download the books electronically. Visit our online store&lt;/i&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.mediblestore.com&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Medibles Store&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/div&gt;

title: “Male Menopause” Also Known as Andropause
content: &lt;p style=&quot;text-align: justify;&quot;&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;text-align: justify;&quot;&gt;Testosterone impacts everything in a man from his muscles, brain and sex drive, to his blood, arteries, organs and glands. A deficiency in testosterone can be devastating with symptoms including: erectile dysfunction, weight gain, depression/irritability and lack of mental clarity, among other symptoms.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;text-align: justify;&quot;&gt;The problem starts when the testicles slowly begin to reduce testosterone production at around age 30. By the time a man reaches his 50s, he may be feeling miserable. This slow but eminent progression is called Andropause, the clinical term sometimes coined as male menopause. A man over the age of 40 needs to think about having his testosterone checked with a simple blood test to determine a baseline for the next decades of his life. Addressing the symptoms of low testosterone is not enough. I suggest forgoing the injections, creams, gels, patches and erectile dysfunction drugs. They may provide temporary relief but will do nothing to achieve the homeostatic environment, or internal equilibrium in which your internal systems thrive. This can only be achieved by adjusting your bodys physiological processes using low-dose, bio-identical testosterone pellets, such as the method found with SottoPelle Therapy. This methodology provides a 24/7 delivery of testosterone- just like your body used to at your peak condition.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;text-align: justify;&quot;&gt;Your hormone deficiency is determined from the results of your blood work and symptoms. The pellets are injected into the hip and can last anywhere from 4 to 5 months; the more active the patient, the faster the pellet will dissolve.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;text-align: justify;&quot;&gt;Not all pellets or physicians are created equally. Synthetic hormones can be harmful to your health and not all physicians are trained to provide hormonal replacement. Do your research, ask questions, and get a second opinion. Dont just mask the symptoms, balance your body from the inside out.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;text-align: justify;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;We wish all the Fathers a Happy Fathers Day!&lt;strong&gt;Have fun spending time with your children this weekend!&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;text-align: justify;&quot;&gt;&lt;a title=&quot;Gino Tutera MD FACOG&quot; href=&quot;/?page_id=39&quot;&gt;Gino Tutera M.D. FACOG&lt;/a&gt;, is recognized as a pioneer and leader in the field of bio-identical hormone replacement therapy. For more information, visit &lt;a title=&quot;Hormone Replacement Therapy&quot; href=&quot;/?page_id=2&quot;&gt;SottoPelle Therapy&lt;/a&gt;and look for the self-test questionnaire or call us at 480.874.1515.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;text-align: justify;&quot;&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

title: Do's and Dont's for Women Entering Menopause
content: &lt;p style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;Women entering menopause begin a new phase of their life. With the copious amount of information available on menopause between books and websites, many feel overwhelmed by this new phase and the abundance of symptoms they face. Its helpful to have a list of informational Dos and Donts to follow when entering this chapter of your life.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;b&gt;DO&lt;/b&gt;&lt;ul&gt;&lt;li&gt;&lt;b&gt;Do Consult your Physician&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ul&gt;It is highly recommended to begin discussing menopause with your own physician so you are more informed on the subject and begin the discussion of hormone pellet replacement therapy.&lt;ul&gt;&lt;li&gt;&lt;b&gt;Do Begin Hormone Pellet Replacement Therapy &lt;/b&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ul&gt;Hormone pellet replacement therapy differs from creams by remaining in your body and using your internal system to regulate what your body knows it needs and when. Unlike other methods, Hormone Pellet Replacement Therapy does not invite foreign synthetics into your body. This method uses pure hormone and a small percentage of human fatty acid to work with the existing hormones in your body.&lt;ul&gt;&lt;li&gt;&lt;b&gt;Do Maintain a Healthy Lifestyle&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ul&gt;By maintaining a healthy lifestyle, women going through menopause have a higher likelihood of gaining weight during this time. By being active and eating properly you will gain more energy and make menopause more comfortable.&lt;ul&gt;&lt;li&gt;&lt;b&gt;Do Get Enough Sleep&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ul&gt;By getting seven to nine hours of sleep, you will decrease your risk for mood swings and increase your energy.&amp;nbsp;&lt;b&gt;DONT&lt;/b&gt;&lt;ul&gt;&lt;li&gt;&lt;b&gt;Dont Self-Medicate&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ul&gt;In the midst of an uncomfortable hot flash, a menopausal headache or sore muscles, it may seem ideal to begin self-medicating. However, this can lead down a dangerous path filled with numerous side effects and can actually worsen your symptoms.&lt;ul&gt;&lt;li&gt;&lt;b&gt;Dont Use Hormone Creams&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ul&gt;Using vaginal estrogen creams may lead to inflammation and infection of the vagina. Increasing the chance of vaginal pain.&lt;ul&gt;&lt;li&gt;&lt;b&gt;Dont Ignore your Symptoms&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ul&gt;Instead of disregarding symptoms as being part of getting older, you should discuss them with your primary doctor. By having a discussion you could discover a solution that allows you to live your life without being restricted by menopausal symptoms.&lt;ul&gt;&lt;li&gt;&lt;b&gt;Dont Take on Too Many Responsibilities &lt;/b&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ul&gt;By reducing your responsibilities you can decrease excessive stress in your life which can allow you to avoid symptoms such as depression and mood swings that increase during menopause.&amp;nbsp;It is of great importance that you discuss your options with your doctor to choose the best course of action for you.&amp;nbsp;Author: &lt;a title=&quot;Gino Tutera MD FACOG&quot; href=&quot;/?page_id=39&quot;&gt;Dr. Gino Tutera&lt;/a&gt; is recognized worldwide as a pioneer and leader in the field of &lt;a title=&quot;Bio-Identical Hormones&quot; href=&quot;/?page_id=268&quot;&gt;bio-identical hormone&lt;/a&gt; replacement therapy. He haspracticedmedicine for over thirty years and specializes in natural hormone therapy.In 2002, Dr. Tutera founded SottoPelle Therapy, but he has been an industry leader in performing pellet therapy since 1992. Visit &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.sottopelletherapy.com&quot;&gt;www.sottopelletherapy.com&lt;/a&gt; for more information or call 480-874-1515

title: Six Signs of Male Hormone Imbalance
content: &lt;p style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.sottopelletherapy.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/06/28729_Ick3rNcZ1eOopxk.jpg&quot;&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;As men age they may begin to experience symptoms commonly associated with growing older. However, certain symptoms may be signs of hormone imbalance due to andropause. The following are six common signs that may be due to hormonal changes in men.&lt;ul&gt;&lt;li&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Thinning of Hair &amp;amp; Loss of Body Hair&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ul&gt;Decreased testosterone levels leads to loss of scalp and body hair because an imbalance of testosterone to Dihydrotestosterone (DHT) exists. . DHT inhibits the growth of new hair cells and hair cells are not replaced after they fall out when DHT activity is higher than testosterone activity.&lt;ul&gt;&lt;li&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Weight Gain&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ul&gt;Weight gain is commonly reported by men during andropause. The decrease in testosterone levels leads to higher insulin and cortisol levels. When men have high cortisol levels, their bodies can increase the production of fat cells and increases appetite. High levels of insulin and cortisol also decreases metabolism and continues to decrease testosterone. The combination of these effects leads to weight gain.&lt;ul&gt;&lt;li&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Decreased Libido&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ul&gt;As energy decreases with lower testosterone levels, mens sex drive often follows. The libido is considered highly dependent on hormone levels and is affected by the changes in hormones as men enter andropause. The loss of energy and strength during this time in a mans life also plays into a lowered libido, as does less stimulation of the libido center in the brain.&lt;ul&gt;&lt;li&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Trouble sleeping&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ul&gt;Low testosterone and heightened cortisol levels can lead to sleep apnea. Because human growth hormones are made during the first ninety minutes of sleep, interrupted sleep leads to the disruption of hormone production. When sleep is interrupted it can lead to worsened fatigue and insomnia, as well as, reduce insulin sensitivity.&lt;ul&gt;&lt;li&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Depression&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ul&gt;Depression is a common side effect of decreased testosterone. Decreased testosterone leads to lower serotonin levels in the brain. Often times, men are not accustomed to being vocal about their emotions, but it is important for them to share these feelings with a medical professional as it may be a symptom of low testosterone.&lt;ul&gt;&lt;li&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Muscle Loss&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ul&gt;Testosterone is a major component in the production of strong muscles in men. As the testosterone decreases in men, their muscle strength can also decrease as they lose energy and their bodies begin turning muscle fibers into fat.&amp;nbsp;It is important to speak to your doctor about any symptoms you are having. Even if you may not see a connection between what you are experiencing and the possible cause of it, a trained medical professional can advise.

title: The Truth about the Journal of the American Medical Association Study
content: &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.sottopelletherapy.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/07/Cow-with-syringe.jpg&quot;&gt;&lt;/a&gt;A new study has been making waves in the medical community. A &lt;a href=&quot;http://http://archinte.jamanetwork.com/article.aspx?articleid=1700432&quot;&gt;study was recently released from the Journal of the American Medical Association&lt;/a&gt; on the long term side effects from hormonal treatments for menopausal and post-menopausal women. The study found that 1,326 women who were taking synthetic hormones for more than seven years had no risk to cognitive functions from the ages 50-55 but that there was some cognitive decline in women age 65 and older.This study may seem frightening to those on or considering hormonal treatment but a closer look shows its flaws. One of the major flaws found by experts was the use of conjugated equine estrogen which is found in horse urine. This hormone replacement should never be used in humans. It does not produce protective effects that human estradiol does. It also causes increased breast stimulation. By performing the study with the basis flawed it created results that may not be typical of natural estrogen replacement therapies.SottoPelle uses high-quality bio identical 17-Beta Estradiol hormone pellets. 17-Beta Estradiol is the only estrogen that improves cognition of the brain, no other estrogen does this. These pellets are completely identical to the hormones naturally produced by your own body. They are derived by botanicals but are 100 percent identical to those already in your body. In no way whatsoever is conjugated equine estrogen used in SottoPelle Therapy.The study done by the Journal of American Medical Association had a fundamental flaw when it used conjugated equine estrogen instead of a bio-identical hormone replacement. It is known that equine estrogen has negative effects before the study was concluded and is used in bio-identical hormone replacement therapies. This overlooked variable created negative results that should have no bearing on other therapies as they are not structurally similar.If you would like to learn more about options for bio-identical hormone replacement using pellets, please visit &lt;a href=&quot;/?page_id=341&quot;&gt;http://www.sottopelletherapy.com/find-a-location/&lt;/a&gt;

title: Menopause Monday: When the Summer Weather isn’t why you’re Hot: Hot Flashes
content: &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.sottopelletherapy.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/07/b207ddc5c69736aa5d47d7b46b3d9f55.jpg&quot;&gt;&lt;/a&gt;As women enter the next phase of their life with perimenopause, menopause or postmenopause, the most common symptom is the infamous hot flash. Knowledge is one of the greatest weapons and when it comes to hot flashes, it is essential to arm yourself with the correct information to take action. By learning about hot flashes and consulting your doctor, you can be more prepared in what you could be dealing with.&lt;b&gt;What are hot flashes?&lt;/b&gt;Low estrogen is often the main cause of hot flashes in women. Low estrogen has a harsh effect on the hypothalamus, the part of the brain that controls sleep, appetite, sex hormones and temperature. The hypothalamus is deceived by low estrogen levels into believing that the body is too hot and attempts to remedy it by ridding the body of excess heat. Hot flashes are the dilation of blood vessels at the skins surface attempting to cool down your body. Instead of experiencing a cooling effect you feel suddenly warm. This feeling is usually most intense in the face, neck and chest. Sometimes a hot flash can cause a reddening or blotchiness of the skin, which is referred to as a hot flush. A hot flash can also be accompanied by perspiration, a rapid heartbeat, or chills. By balancing your hormones, you can put an end to hot flashes.&lt;b&gt;What can you do to ease hot flashes? &lt;/b&gt;&lt;ul&gt;&lt;li&gt;Stay cool&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ul&gt;When a hot flash strikes, you can remove an article of clothing to keep your body temperature stable. Another option is to decrease a rooms temperature by either opening a window or using a fan of some sort. This will also keep the air flowing throughout the room which helps keep your body comfortable.&lt;ul&gt;&lt;li&gt;Relax&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ul&gt;It is important to remember that these hot flashes are not signs of a medical problem. They are only your bodys response to changing hormones and often will ease in intensity after the first or second year of menopause. Rhythmic breathing exercises can help keep you calm and focused. Reducing stress can be imperative for keeping your body stability.&lt;ul&gt;&lt;li&gt;Stay Hydrated&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ul&gt;Drinking cold water before, during, and after a flash can help keep your body hydrated and stable.&lt;b&gt;How can you prevent hot flashes? &lt;/b&gt;&lt;ul&gt;&lt;li&gt;Bioidentical Hormone Replacement Therapy (BHRT)&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ul&gt;BHRT continues to be one of the most effective treatments for preventing hot flashes. By using hormone pellets you can experience complete relief of your hot flash symptoms along with other uncomfortable menopausal effects such as vaginal dryness and night sweats. The pellets can work with your body for up to six months and you dont have to worry about taking a pill or using a cream every day.&lt;ul&gt;&lt;li&gt;Exercise&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ul&gt;Exercising can help reduce the intensity of your hot flashes and help in preventing them. Fat cells store estrogen and by reducing your fat cells your body can more effectively regulate the estrogen in your body.&amp;nbsp;&lt;ul&gt;&lt;li&gt;Avoid triggers&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ul&gt;By avoiding certain triggers such as stress, caffeine, alcohol, smoking and spicy foods you can sometimes evade hot flashes.

title: Testosterone Doesn't Up MI or Stroke: May Be Protective?
content: Miriam E. TuckerMay18,2014 LAS VEGAS Contrary to recent findings, a new retrospective study of data from 40 specialized clinics around the United States has found that testosterone therapy in men is not associated with an increased risk for myocardial infarction (MI) or stroke and may even be cardioprotective.The late-breaking results were presented here at the American Association of Clinical Endocrinologists (AACE) 23rd Annual Scientific and Clinical Congress by Robert Tan, MD, director of the Opal Medical Clinic, Houston, research director of the Low T Institute, and clinical professor of family and community medicine at the University of Texas.Among 19,968 hypogonadal men who received testosterone therapy during a 5-year period (20092014) at Low T Centers nationwide (www.lowtcenter.com), the risk for MI was 7-fold lower and the risk for stroke 9 times lower compared with samples from the general population. Further, there was no evidence of worsening of preexisting MI or stroke in patients treated with testosterone.&quot;There has been a lot of hype and concern....I want to try to explain the other side of the story,&quot; Dr. Tan said in introducing his presentation.He told Medscape Medical News, &quot;When compared with other databases looking at rates of MI and strokes, it appears testosterone is cardioprotective.&quot;This finding is counter to those of 2 widely reported recent studies that have generated enormous controversy and prompted an investigation into testosterone safety by the US Food and Drug Administration and the European Medicines Agency. The US Endocrine Society has also called for randomized controlled trials to investigate testosterone therapy and cardiovascular risk and has advised against giving testosterone therapy to men who have had a recent cardiovascular event.But others have hit back, including the US Androgen Study Group, which has highlighted what it says are key flaws in these 2 widely cited studies; it is campaigning for 1 of them to be retracted and also claims that numerous other studies have shown a protective effect of testosterone.Session moderator and AACE president-elect George Grunberger, MD, founder of the Grunberger Diabetes Institute, Bloomfield Hills, Michigan, told Medscape Medical News that he thinks Dr. Tans study results &quot;will help. Hopefully, it will reduce pushback from patients. The last thing you want is for people to stop out of fear.&quot;However, although he called the new findings &quot;very encouraging,&quot; he said that because the study was retrospective, it is not definitive. &quot;This wasnt a prospective trial. The gold standard is a randomized controlled trial to answer the question.&quot;&lt;strong&gt;Does Testosterone Protect?&lt;/strong&gt;The new study was part of an internal quality-management program at the Low T Centers, which follow strict protocols requiring a definitive diagnosis of hypogonadism (total T &amp;lt; 350 ng/dL and free T &amp;lt; 10 ng/dL) for starting testosterone therapy. Patients are also closely monitored while on treatment, with regular 1- or 2-week physical assessments and laboratory work.Data were extracted from the electronic health record. In addition, the centers were called to make sure that International Classification of Diseases, Ninth Edition (ICD-9) coding had been updated, and families of patients who had MIs or strokes were also interviewed.Of 39,937 patients seen during 20092014, approximately 50% met the criteria for treatment. Of the treated patients, 4 had nonfatal MIs, and 3 had probable fatal MIs, giving a rate of 30 new MIs per 100,000. Of the 46 patients with pretherapy MIs, none had adverse outcomes after receiving testosterone, Dr. Tan said.There were 2 strokes among the treated patients, giving a rate of 10 new strokes per 100,000. Of 12 patients with pretherapy stroke, none had adverse events after testosterone.Because the patients who did not qualify for testosterone therapy were not followed up, Dr. Tan and colleagues compared their figures with those from other published data sets of the general population.The rate for MI at Kaiser Permanente Northern California was 208 per 100,000, and the stroke rate found in the Northern Manhattan Registry was 93 per 100,000.Compared with these numbers, Dr Tan reported the rate ratio (RR) for MI in the testosterone-treated Low T Center patients was 0.14 (P &amp;lt; .0001), a 7-fold lower risk, and for stroke, the RR was 0.107 (P &amp;lt; .0001), 9-fold lower than the general population.&quot;Our study showed that carefully monitored testosterone therapy may actually protect against MI and stroke. Its retrospective, but I think for now its as good as we can come up with. At least from our experience, there was no evidence of increased heart attacks or strokes from people treated with testosterone,&quot; Dr. Tan observed.But what is really needed, he told Medscape Medical News, is &quot;a large, randomized controlled study with very careful monitoring of patients compliance, hematocrit, and other preexisting cardiac risk factors over at least a 5-year period.&quot;&lt;strong&gt;Why the Differences?&lt;/strong&gt;There are many possible explanations for the difference in findings, Dr. Tan told Medscape Medical News.One of the recently quoted studies showing a 36% increased risk for MI among 55,593 men who received a new prescription for testosterone therapy, published in PLoS One earlier this year, was based on a heterogeneous patient population that was seen at different practices with different protocols and that received varying exposures to testosterone for less than 3 months duration.In contrast, the Low T Center population was more a homogeneous group, received regular follow-ups, and had longer exposure to testosterone therapy, he noted.And in the other oft-cited recent study ? published in JAMA in November 2013 and found a 30% increased risk for death, MI, or ischemic stroke among 1223 older veterans on testosterone therapy who underwent coronary angiography ? Dr. Tan said the mean T level with treatment was only 332.2 ng/dL, &quot;which is at the low end. Our patients reached, on average, 543 ng/dL. Perhaps the lower range in the JAMA study led to the increased risk of MI?&quot;He also noted that one-third of the patients in the JAMA study received testosterone patches, whereas 90% of Low T Center patients received testosterone via injection, and fewer than 1% used the patch. Moreover, only 60% of the JAMA study patients had their testosterone levels reassessed, whereas 100% of Low T Center patients receive such reassessments. &quot;I think close monitoring for safety is essential in testosterone therapy,&quot; Dr. Tan said.&lt;strong&gt;The RCT Dilemma&lt;/strong&gt;In conversation with reporters about the new study, Dr. Grunberger said, &quot;This is hypothesis-generating. Lets do a real study. I was glad to see this, and it is important, but you have to take it at face value when you look at retrospective chart review....Before you start making claims, you need truly high-level, classy randomized trial .&quot;Of course, he noted, &quot;RCTs cost hundreds of millions of dollars. Thats the dilemma we have with everything we do.&quot; And they also take a long time, particularly when they are designed to look at end points such as cardiovascular events, and companies often say they cannot afford the investment.&quot;The economics, the math is just incredibly complex....Thats the sad reality. I really dont know if theres a shortcut. You try to enrich with people at high risk, but then theyre not representative of the general population. So, clinicians just have to fly by the seat of their pants....Thats the dilemma.&quot;The study was unfunded. Dr. Tan is an active practitioner of testosterone therapy in his own clinical practice at Opal Medical Clinic, which is unrelated to Low T Centers. He analyzed the data but does not see patients at the Low T Centers. His coauthors do, however. He has not received any pharmaceutical honoraria or research grants in the past 5 years. Dr. Grunberger has received speaker honoraria from Amarin, Janssen, Merck, Sanofi, Santarus, Takeda, and Valeritas. He has received research support from Bristol-Myers Squibb, Eli Lilly, and Novo Nordisk.American Association of Clinical Endocrinologists (AACE) 23rd Annual Scientific and Clinical Congress. Presented May 16, 2014.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Medscape Medical News2014WebMD, LLC&amp;nbsp;Send comments and news tips to news@medscape.net.&amp;nbsp;Cite this article: Testosterone Doesnt Up MI or Stroke: May Be Protective?Medscape.May18,2014.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;

title: How to Deal With Symptoms of Menopause
content: Many women hear the word menopause and start to think of hot flashes and night sweats. They get nervous and sweat. Cry! Although this is a phase of life for every woman experiences, there is often a sense of embarrassment and dread. Women typically think that they are now considered old. Nothing could be further from the truth. Think back to High School health class and it teaches us that menopause ends ones fertility, but it tends to leave out that a woman can still remain healthy, sexual and vital after they go through menopause. Like any other milestone in our life, menopause is just another phase. How we manage that phase physically, mentally, and socially impacts how well the transition and outcome will be.Menopause occurs when a woman stops menstruating and usually happens when they are in their 40s or 50s, sometimes as early as their twenties. Illness or surgery can alter the onset of menopause for some women. When a woman starts to go through menopause, her body undergoes a series of changes that bring on a variety of symptoms. Some women dont treat their symptoms at all and suffer, while others complain about being uncomfortable.Here are a few ways to deal with symptoms of menopause:&lt;ol&gt;&lt;li&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Hot Flashes&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ol&gt;Women experiencing hot flashes suddenly become very hot out of nowhere and theyll start to sweat. We all experience different triggers, so its good to notice what those triggers are and how they can be avoided. Such triggers include: stress, caffeine, spicy foods, alcohol or just being in a very hot place. Its recommended to dress in layers so that they can be removed with a hot flash happens and to use a fan at home or at work. Also, taking deep, slow breaths when a hot flash starts can prevent one from becoming too hot and bothered.&amp;nbsp;&lt;ol start=&quot;2&quot;&gt;&lt;li&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Vaginal Dryness&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ol&gt;During menopause women tend to be more self-conscious of their bodies, it is important to keep your romantic and sexual life comfortable and ongoing as it will also help with your self-esteem. Menopause can make a womans vagina become unusually dry and the tissue becomes thinner, so if you are experiencing discomfort discuss it with your doctor.&amp;nbsp;&lt;ol start=&quot;3&quot;&gt;&lt;li&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Sleeping Problems&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ol&gt;Sleep seems to evade most women during menopause. The lack of sleep only worsens the other symptoms you may be experiencing. Some suggested ways to help get some rest is to be physically active throughout the day. Also, avoid large meals before bedtime and try drinking something warm before sleeping like warm milk or caffeine-free tea. If you wake up at night and cant go back to sleep, do something relaxing like reading a book until you are sleepy again. But if you cant get to sleep on your own, you might have to talk to your doctor about these sleep problems.&amp;nbsp;&lt;ol start=&quot;4&quot;&gt;&lt;li&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Mood Swings&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ol&gt;Some women feel crankier and moodier than usual when menopause hits them, so its important that they get enough sleep and rest to feel their best. Also, avoid stress and look for positive ways to ease any stress you might have. Women often find themselves very depressed during menopause. If you feel yourself unable to function, you should contact a medical professional for assistance. Hormonal imbalance during this time can wreak havoc with your moods and emotional stability. Having support with friends, family, or group can help in dealing with some of the symptoms.&amp;nbsp;&lt;ol start=&quot;5&quot;&gt;&lt;li&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Memory Problems&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ol&gt;When going through menopause, a common complaint is of memory trouble. The best thing to do is to stay physically active and get enough sleep to improve these symptoms. Also, mental exercises can keep memory lapses at bay.Women can always do something to lessen their symptoms when going through menopause, but they can also talk to their doctors about taking bio identical hormone therapy that can ease or even eliminate the symptoms caused by menopause.&amp;nbsp;

title: Your Healthcare Records and Identity Theft
content: &lt;h2 class=&quot;post-header&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://www.lifelockunlocked.com/protecting-yourself/healthcare-records-identity-theft/&quot;&gt;Guest Blog - Lifelock &lt;/a&gt;&lt;/h2&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;post-meta&quot;&gt;&lt;/div&gt;When I pick up a prescription at the pharmacy, the clerk confirms my identity by asking me for my street address. When I visit the doctor, the front-desk person confirms my identity by asking for my birth month and date.Each time this happens, Im reminded how much both businessesthe drug retailer and the medical groupknow about me. While the drug retailer may not have my Social Security number, at least I dont &lt;em&gt;think&lt;/em&gt; they do, they have enough of my personally identifiable information (PII) that a cyber-criminal could do some damage to my good name if the companys computer systems were hacked.And gosh, the medical group has it allSocial, full name, address, birthdate, health insurance data and, of course, my medical history. If its computer systems were hacked, I could be pretty vulnerable to all sorts of identity theftfor years to come.Hey, pharmacy! Hey, medical group! Are you folks on this? Like &lt;em&gt;seriously&lt;/em&gt; on it?What made me think of this was &lt;a href=&quot;http://online.wsj.com/articles/protect-your-medical-data-from-identity-theft-1415986497&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;a recent article&lt;/a&gt; in The Wall Street Journal on healthcare records and identity theft. And there was one quote in particular that caught my eye:&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 30px;&quot;&gt;&lt;em&gt;Digitized records are much easier to steal than paper ones. Once you needed a convoy to haul away records. Now all you need is a thumb drive.&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/p&gt;That quotes from Deborah Peel, a physician and founder of Patient Privacy Rights, a nonprofit advocacy group in Austin, Texas. And it really hit home.Think about it: Weve heard a lot of in recent years about making our healthcare records more portable, so we could easily move them from doctor to doctor and hospital to hospital. The last time I changed doctors, when mine retired, I had to request in writingtwicethat my former doctors office personnel copy and send my handwritten medical charts to my new doctor. My new medical group is a lot more technologically savvy. They have a smartphone app for scheduling appointments, for crying out loud!Butif patient data is digitized, that makes it so much more vulnerable than when it sat in physical folders in a doctors office. No convoy needed. A neer-do-well employee or a determined and savvy cybercriminal with access could make quick work of it.And in fact, in 2013, health care data made up 43 percent of major data breaches reported. This, according to the &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.idtheftcenter.org/images/breach/UPDATED_ITRC_Breach_Stats_Report_Summary_2013.pdf&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Identity Theft Resource Center&lt;/a&gt;.How should you protect yourself? Above all, protect your Social Security number. Just because someone asks for it, doesnt mean you have to provide it.These additional tips come from the book, &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.amazon.com/Stolen-Identity-Anyone-Birthdate-Security/dp/0692234837&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Stolen Identity&lt;/a&gt;, by author Katie Morell and published earlier this year by LifeLock:&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 30px;&quot;&gt; Guard your insurance card like a credit card.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 30px;&quot;&gt; A common practice for a lost or stolen credit card is to order a new one with a new number. But what if you lose your medical insurance card? Always ask for a new number, because otherwise someone can use that lost or stolen card to get medical services and the claim will go through as if you are the patient.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 30px;&quot;&gt; Check your Explanation of Benefits forms&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 30px;&quot;&gt; Read the Explanation of Benefits (EOB) documents that come in the ?mail or online following a doctors visit or medical procedure. (They ?usually state THIS IS NOT A BILL at the top.)&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 30px;&quot;&gt; Shred all medical-related documents, including bills and papers that ?contain financial information.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 30px;&quot;&gt; Keep accurate records of all doctors appointments and medical ?procedures.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 30px;&quot;&gt; Once per year, request from your health insurance carrier a list of ?benefits that they paid in your name.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;em&gt;Posted by Cory Warren, editor&lt;/em&gt;
