title: A Green Diet for St. Patrick’s Day
content: Four leaf clovers, leprechauns, and green beer all are very green to commemorate St. Pattys Day, but you can be green and healthy too. One of the exciting things this St. Pattys Day is it also means spring is coming soon. The SottoPelle Team has searched for a few green recipes for you to enjoy!!! Send us your favorite healthy St. Patricks Day recipe or let us know if you enjoyed the ones listed here.Celebrate being green the healthy way. Some healthy ideas on eating:&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 30px;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Breakfast&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;Try your Smoothie Green (http://thecornerkitchenblog.com/green-smoothies/)&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt; 1 - 1 1/2 cups unsweetened almond milk, depending on how thick you like your smoothie&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt; 1 cup kale leaves, center rib removed&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt; 1 cup baby spinach&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt; 1 banana, frozen &amp;amp; cut into pieces&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt; 1 mango, peeled and cut into pieces&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt; 1 teaspoon fresh ginger&lt;/p&gt;Dr Seuss loves Green Eggs, so today is a good day to try it:&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt; 8 large eggs - beaten&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt; 1 cup chopped frozen spinach - thawed&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt; 1/2 cup low-fat milk&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt; 2 cups bread cubes or small torn pieces of bread&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt; 1/2 cup grated Swiss or Monterey jack cheese (optional)&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt; Salt and pepper to taste (optional)&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt; Read More: http://www.mrbreakfast.com/superdisplay.asp?recipeid=1204&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 30px;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Lunch&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt;&lt;em&gt;Irish Salad - Colcannon&lt;/em&gt; (http://www.goodlifeeats.com/2012/03/colcannon-with-leeks-and-kale.html)&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt;Considered to be a &quot;frugal&quot; dish - but it is healthy and tasty too.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 90px;&quot;&gt;3 - 4 medium sized russet potatoes, peeled and chopped into chunks&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 90px;&quot;&gt;8 ounces red potatoes, peeled and chopped into chunks&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 90px;&quot;&gt;10 ounces parsnips, peeled and sliced&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 90px;&quot;&gt;2 bay leaves&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 90px;&quot;&gt;5 tablespoons butter&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 90px;&quot;&gt;1 leek, cleaned and chopped&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 90px;&quot;&gt;4 ounces kale, chopped&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 90px;&quot;&gt;1 - 1 1/2 cup whole milk&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 90px;&quot;&gt;1 teaspoon salt, or to taste&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 90px;&quot;&gt;1/4 teaspoon black pepper, or to taste&lt;/p&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;em&gt;Green Tomatoes and Mozzarella -&lt;/em&gt; Make your typical Caprese Salad green by replacing red tomatoes with green ones. (http://www.kalynskitchen.com/2010/08/recipe-for-green-goddess-tomato.html)&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt;8 slices fresh tomato (make all slices about the same diameter, I used Green Zebra tomatoes)&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt;4 slices fresh mozzarella&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt;3-4 T Green Goddess Salad Dressing&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 30px;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Pub Snacks&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 30px;&quot;&gt;What is St. Pattys Day without some Pub food?&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 30px;&quot;&gt;(http://kblog.lunchboxbunch.com/2013/03/lucky-leprechaun-dip-creamy-green.html)&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 30px;&quot;&gt;Feel Lucky with &lt;em&gt;Green Leprechaun Dip&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt;1 can white cannellini beans (1 1/2 cups) - drain/rinse in hot water&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt;1 cup kale (I actually used frozen kale! But fresh works too)&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt;4 Tbsp. extra virgin olive oil&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt;2 Tbsp. apple cider vinegar&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt;2 tsp lemon juice + generous pinch of lemon zest&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt;1/2 tsp fine black pepper&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt;3 dashes of cayenne&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt;1/4 cup raw cashews (no need to soak if using a high speed blender or food processor)&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt;1 1/2 Tbsp. tahini, roasted, organic&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt;1/4+ cup warm water&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt;1/4 cup chopped parsley, flat-leaf&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt;Optional: garlic powder or roasted garlic&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 30px;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Dinner&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 30px;&quot;&gt;&lt;em&gt;Green Pizza&lt;/em&gt; (See recipe http://www.eatingwell.com/recipes/arugula_broccoli_pesto_pizza.html)&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt; 1 pound prepared pizza dough, preferably whole-wheat&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt; 2 cups chopped broccoli florets&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt; 1/4 cup water&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt; 5 ounces arugula, any tough stems removed, chopped (about 6 cups)&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt; Pinch of salt&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt; Freshly ground pepper to taste&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt; 1/2 cup prepared pesto&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt; 1 cup shredded part-skim mozzarella cheese&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 30px;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Dessert&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt;Ice Cream can be healthy and green too. This creative Greek yogurt recipe combines health, green, and ice cream for an amazing dessert.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt;&lt;em&gt;Mint Chocolate Chip Greek Yogurt Ice Cream&lt;/em&gt; (See: http://immaeatthat.com/2013/01/07/chobani-recipes-mint-chocolate-chip-ice-cream/)&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt;2 frozen bananas&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt;3/4 cup almond milk, original&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt;2 cups spinach, packed&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt;1 container (16 ounces) Chobani Vanilla Chocolate Chunk Greek Yogurt&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt;1/4 tsp mint extract&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt;3 Tbsp. dark chocolate chips, roughly chopped&lt;/p&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;strong&gt;Green Beer&lt;/strong&gt; has lots of carbs, and you feel like having a healthy spirit? We found this interesting twist on green alcoholic drink. (See http://www.telegraph.co.uk/foodanddrink/healthy-recipes/10909277/Healthy-green-juice-with-an-alcoholic-twist.html)50ml fresh green juice (I use 1 cucumber, 3 apples, 4 large curly kale leaves, 2 pears)25ml sugar syrup or elderflower cordial25ml fresh lime juice50ml vodka&lt;p style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;So be healthy, eat and drink in moderation and BE GREEN this St. Patricks Day!!&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;em&gt;***If youre allergic to any ingredients noted then omit from recipe or replace with suitable item.&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;em&gt;Additional Link: http://greatist.com/health/healthy-green-recipes-st-patricks-day&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

title: Guest Post by Dr. James Mirabile, MD, FACOG on Chronic Pelvic Pain
content: &lt;strong&gt;CHRONIC PELVIC PAIN&lt;/strong&gt;is pain that occurs below the belly button and has lasted longer than six months in duration. As one of the most common medical problems affecting women, it is estimated that as many as one out of every five women age 18-50 has chronic pelvic pain that has lasted longer than a year. Additionally, one out of every ten visits to the gynecologists office is related to pelvic pain. Longstanding chronic pelvic pain can have a significant impact on the physical, emotional and social well-being of a woman. The process of evaluating, diagnosing and treating chronic pelvic pain requires patience, empathy and understanding from both the patient and the physician.&lt;strong&gt;Causes of Chronic Pelvic Pain&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;The four most common causes of chronic pelvic pain are: endometriosis, irritable bowel syndrome, pelvic scarring/adhesions, and painful bladder syndrome (also known as interstitial cystitis).Most people assume that pelvic pain only arises from the female reproductive organs (i.e. uterus, ovaries, fallopian tubes and vagina). However, organs from other body systems may also cause pain in the pelvic region. The bladder, colon, and the muscles of the pelvic floor or the front area of your abdomen can also cause chronic pelvic pain.Additionally, chronic pelvic pain may arise from scar tissue (or adhesions) that arises after a person has had pelvic or abdominal surgery, or from damaged nerves in the pelvic area. In fact, up to 50% of women with chronic pelvic pain will have more than one source of the pain. Also, prolonged pain in one organ may cause pain in another organ system over time. The multi-system etiology of pelvic pain often makes the diagnosis and management challenging for both patient and physician.&lt;strong&gt;Other Causes of Chronic Pelvic Pain by Organ System&lt;/strong&gt; Gynecological System: Chronic pelvic and uterine infections, dilated and congestedveins in the pelvic area, uterine fibroid GI System: Chronic constipation, Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohns Disease orUlcerative Colitis) Urological System: Recurrent urinary tract infections, bladder injury Musculoskeletal System: Fibromyalgia, Pelvic Floor Myalgia, Poor Posture, ChronicLow Back Pain, Trigger Points&lt;strong&gt;What are the &lt;/strong&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Symptoms?&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;The symptoms of chronic pelvic pain vary widely among women. Some women may have a mild, dull constant ache in the pelvis. Others may experience sharp, intense pelvic pain that may greatly limit their normal activities. Other symptoms associated with chronic pelvic pain include pain with intercourse (dyspareunia), pain with urination, and bowel movements, pain with menstrual cycles (dysmenorrhea), pain in the lower back that may radiate down the leg, and a feeling of constant heaviness in the pelvic area.Additionally, dealing with long-standing chronic pelvic pain can affect the psychological well-being of a woman. As a result, symptoms of depression frequently are found in patients with chronic pelvic pain. In some patients, the pain leads to depression. However, in others both the depression and chronic pelvic pain may be the result of past life traumas. Studies have shown that up to 40-50% of women with chronic pelvic pain have a history of physical or sexual abuse. The symptoms of chronic pelvic pain can exhibit a strong mind-body connection. It is important to be very open with your physician and always expect confidentiality.&lt;strong&gt;Diagnosis&lt;/strong&gt;The initial work-up may include a combination of the following: blood tests, urinalysis, screening for pelvic infections, pap smear, pelvic ultrasound, CT scan, or MRI, laparoscopy of the pelvis and abdomen, and cystoscopy of the bladder. The choice and extent of diagnostic testing is guided by the findings during the history and physical exam. Diagnosing and treating chronic pelvic pain requires patience and open mindedness. In some patients the diagnosis may be clearly evident from a few diagnostic tests. In others, the diagnosis may require more extensive work, and is often a process of elimination involving the most likely causes of the pain. Obtaining a detailed history is key in the evaluation process. Therefore, it is important that patients prepare for their initial visit with a mental or written list of symptoms, medical and surgical history and any prior evaluations that have been performed to evaluate the pain. While the initial evaluation of chronic pelvic pain often begins with the gynecologist, some patients may require additional evaluation by other specialists including urologists, gastroenterologists, neurologists, pain specialists, physical therapists and psychologists.&lt;strong&gt;Treatments&lt;/strong&gt;While the optimal goal of any treatment is to provide a cure, the reality is that in many cases long-standing chronic pelvic pain is not curable. Instead, the goal is to decrease the pain symptoms so that a woman may improve her quality of life and increase her functional activities. Straightforward cases of chronic pelvic pain can be treated with a single treatment plan. However, in most cases, the multi-organ system etiology of chronic pain requires a detailed approach to treatment. Depending on the cause of the pain, treatment may include a combination of medications, surgery, behavioral therapy and physical therapy. The results from treatment may not be instant, and in some cases may take up to several months to provide relief. The treatment process can be long and frustrating as several combinations of therapy may be necessary before finding the effective one. Remember the disease was chronic and pain relief is possible with time, patience and collaboration between the patient and physician.&lt;strong&gt;To learn more or to schedule an appointment for a complete evaluation, please call us at 913.888.7546.&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;em&gt;To Your Health! James Mirabile, MD, FACOG&lt;/em&gt;

title: Menopause Monday: Six Signs of Female Hormone Imbalance
content: &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.sottopelletherapy.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/07/menopause-in-blocks.jpg&quot;&gt;&lt;/a&gt;As women age, they encounter numerous issues from a hormone imbalance. Understanding these symptoms help women recognize the role of hormones in their adult years and how they play into their appearance, health and positive outlook on life.&lt;b&gt;1. &lt;/b&gt;&lt;b&gt;Weight Gain&lt;/b&gt;As your body stops ovulating, your ovaries stop producing estrogen. As your bodys source of estrogen is discontinued, it pursues other ways of harvesting this hormone. One source of estrogen is fat cells that produce the hormone. Your body begins to retain these fat cells which causes an increase in weight and presents a difficult time when attempting to lose excess fat. A decrease in progesterone causes your body to retain water and leads to a bloating effect that is doubly unfavorable. A decrease in testosterone leads to muscle and bone loss, as well as, difficulty in burning fat.&lt;b&gt;2. &lt;/b&gt;&lt;b&gt;Insomnia&lt;/b&gt;If you are experiencing difficulty sleeping you may be feeling the effects of a decrease in melatonin. Melatonin is the natural hormone in your body that helps maintain your circadian rhythm. As you age, your levels of melatonin decrease along with estrogen levels. Estrogen helps maintain sleep as well. By not getting enough sleep, the body is not able to heal and rejuvenate itself. A lack of sleep effects many different hormones and tips them off balance. Deficiency in estrogen leads to decreased serotonin levels which make sleeping soundly and getting good quality sleep difficult.&lt;b&gt;3. &lt;/b&gt;&lt;b&gt;Vaginal Dryness&lt;/b&gt;Levels of high progesterone and low estrogen result in the drying of the vaginal walls. The fluctuations of progesterone and estrogen can also lead to increased stress and cause a lack of sexual desire and a low libido. Stress suppresses libido. Low testosterone causes a marked loss in libido and is the major or cause of sexual dysfunction.&amp;nbsp;&lt;strong&gt;Stay tuned for the rest of the article when we remember where it went...&lt;/strong&gt;

title: Six Signs of Female Hormone Imbalance: Part 2
content: &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.sottopelletherapy.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/07/menopause-in-blocks.jpg&quot;&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Part 2:&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Major symptom forgetfulness We remembered what we were looking for!&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;b&gt;4. &lt;/b&gt;&lt;b&gt;Hot Flashes&lt;/b&gt;Low estrogen is often the main cause of hot flashes in women. Low estrogen has a harsh effect on the hypothalamus, the part of the brain that controls sleep, appetite, sex hormones and temperature. The hypothalamus is deceived by low estrogen levels into believing that the body is too hot and attempts to remedy it by ridding the body of excess heat. Low estrogen causes the pituitary gland to over secrete a hormone called FSH which causes hot flashes, irritability and sleeplessness.&amp;nbsp;&lt;b&gt;5. &lt;/b&gt;&lt;b&gt;Mood Swings&lt;/b&gt;Both estrogen and serotonin regulate emotions. During menopause, estrogen fluctuates. This fluctuation leads to a decrease in serotonin. Serotonin is a neurotransmitter that when the levels are altered effects a persons mood. These two factors cause emotional instability that is expressed in mood swings.&amp;nbsp;&lt;b&gt;6. &lt;/b&gt;&lt;b&gt;Foggy Memory&lt;/b&gt;Memory problems during menopause is commonly referred to as a brain fog. This symptom is very common. When the estrogen decreases, there is a diminished proportion of neurotransmitter responsible for communicating within the brain. Low testosterone levels cause decreased stimulation of the major hormone receptors in the temporal lobe of the brain causing loss of memory, decreased focus, decreased problem solving and poor multitasking capability.

title: Menstrual Migraines
content: &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.sottopelletherapy.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/07/imgres.jpg&quot;&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;p style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;If you feel like this when you get migraines, wouldnt you rather feel like this....&lt;/p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.sottopelletherapy.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/07/woman-leaping.jpg&quot;&gt;&lt;/a&gt;Long-lasting is a great word for things like candles, batteries, or pens. But long-lasting is not a word you want to hear when associated with a migraine. Over 36 million people in the U.S. are affected by migraines with women being diagnosed more often. Unfortunately, the cause of migraines is often misdiagnosed leading many down a long path away from true relief from their insufferable pain. Migraines can last up to 72 hours and often are caused by hormonal changes associated with their menstrual cycle.&amp;nbsp;Migraines typical including a variety of severe neurological symptoms often marked by an intense throbbing pain on one side of the head (although in 1/3 ofmigraine attacks, both sides are affected). Symptoms of a migraine along with the pain include visual disturbances, nausea, vomiting, dizziness, extreme sensitivity to sound, light, touch and smell, and tingling or numbness in the extremities or face.Hormones are a main cause of migraines in women. The estrogen hormone is related to signals that trigger your brain to think you are in pain. As estrogen levels drop around the time of a womans menstrual cycle she becomes more susceptible to pain. Serotonin, another hormone, is also a cause for these painful long-lasting headaches. These misdiagnoses can cause women to look for migraine treatments that will never completely work for them because they are not addressing the root of the problem. Menstrual migraines can often leave the victim debilitated and unable to perform usual tasks.&lt;b&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;text-decoration: underline;&quot;&gt;Treatment&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/b&gt;Exercise, regular sleep, and eating healthy foods are a great way to help reduce migraines and relieve the stress that can be contributing to your pain. When a migraine hits it is helpful to rest in a dark room with no extra stimuli and take an over the counter medicine such as Tylenol or Excedrin Migraine though overuse of over the counter pain medicine can result in rebound headaches that make your headaches worse.When speaking about menstrual migraines it is vital to address the role of hormones. Knowing that estrogen and serotonin levels affect the frequency and duration of menstrual migraines it is essential to assess and evaluate these critical hormones. &lt;a title=&quot;What is Hormone Replacement Therapy?&quot; href=&quot;/?page_id=260&quot;&gt;Bioidentical Hormone Replacement Therap&lt;/a&gt;y (BHRT) is a great option to discuss with your doctor because it directly levels your hormone levels so that your body can function to the best of its ability. BHRT works with your body so that you get the right levels of hormones that your body needs.Menstrual migraines cause debilitating pain and can make the sufferer miserable. Living in pain is awful but there is something you can do about it. Addressing your hormones is the first step to living menstrual migraine free. If you believe you have been experiencing menstrual migraines you should speak with a SottoPelle Provider about the options you can pursue, getting your hormone levels tested and the potential of Bioidentical Hormone Replacement Therapy helping to level your hormones and get you headache free.&amp;nbsp;To find a Licensed SottoPelle Provider near you, &lt;a title=&quot;Find A Location&quot; href=&quot;/?page_id=341&quot;&gt;click here.&lt;/a&gt;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;

title: Recognizing Menopausal Symptoms and What To Do Next
content: &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.sottopelletherapy.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/08/7-dwarfs-of-menopause.jpg&quot;&gt;&lt;/a&gt;When Dr. Gino Tutera asks his patients to give him a definition of menopause, he receives a variety of answers that consist of When you get hot flashes to Not having a period for over a year. Many women go under diagnosed because of the failure of physicians to apply a scientific method for diagnosis. Scientifically, a diagnosis is when the level of follicle stimulation hormone (FSH) reaches a level greater than 23 miu/ml, whether she is menstruating or not. Peri-menopause typically begins when a woman is in her 40s and can average 4 to 8 years. Menopause occurs roughly in women their early 50s. Every year it is estimated that 1.3 million women are expected to reach menopause.I will take you through a series of symptoms and what a woman should look for and what should she do next? NO woman should ever have to suffer through any symptom(s) nor feel less than a woman. Menopause is a natural part of the aging process. Not all symptoms will show in all women. Please use this as a guide only.During the menopausal transition women may experience sexual dysfunction as well as depressive symptoms. Due to the loss of estrogen, ones symptoms can also consist of:&lt;ul&gt;&lt;li&gt;Hot flashes&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Severe sweating can happen both day and night&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Insomnia&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Vaginal dryness&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Vaginal discomfort&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Irritability&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Loss of memory or fuzzy thinking&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Cold sweats&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Irregular periods&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Anxiety&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Mood swings&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Headaches&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Sadness&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ul&gt;When a woman comes to me with symptoms, as previously stated, I take the time to listen to what each individual patient is telling me, never discounting any of their feelings or symptoms. My immediate instinct as a Doctor is to help her improve her symptoms and get her on the right track to feeling like a woman again. My first recommendation is that they have a simple blood test that will measure their pituitary hormone Follicle Stimulating Hormone (FSH) level. Depending upon the blood work I get back from their testings, my suggested and most successful form of hormone replacement would be via the Pellet Hormone Delivery System (PHDS). Women who have their hormones replaced via PHDS allows the body to recreate a continuous flow of hormones that the ovaries normally and previously produced within their bodies. This method of delivery is more important than any other type of replacement therapy as it is surgically inserted and allows the body to control the release of the hormones over time. Nothing in an oral, patch or cream can reproduce the normal hormone correction that is needed.Always remember to go with your instinct regarding how you are feeling and if you are displaying some of the symptoms above, as each woman knows best how they should feel and seek the advice of a doctor. Dont ever give in or give up to the ugly face of menopause.Remember to put your fears away, as life during and after menopause can be quite enjoyable!

title: Testosterone Tuesday: Menopause and ADHD
content: Attention-Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) is not just a young boy problem like many misconceive it to me. Even women going through menopause and perimenopause may experience the negative symptoms associated with ADHD. Often times this disorder is not detected in women until they are older and have been experiencing it unknowingly for a long time. ADHD symptoms in adults can vary from those in children. Some ADHD symptoms include disorganization, marital problems, reckless driving, chronic lateness and angry outbursts.A study from the University of Rochester Medical Center (URMC) was conducted with 75 women ages 40 to 60 to determine whether or not brain fogs around the time of menopause are actual cognitive changes. After a battery of tests were conducted the study confirms that they are. The scientists in this study found that particularly when performing a challenging task, a woman can have memory difficulties by not being as capable of keeping her focus and attention on the task at hand.Many patients that come to &lt;a title=&quot;Hormone Replacement Therapy&quot; href=&quot;/?page_id=2&quot;&gt;SottoPelle&lt;/a&gt; complain about memory loss and the inability to focus. With our patients, we have found that low testosterone is a vital factor in the diagnosis of ADHD symptoms. Some others believe that it is low estrogen levels that contribute to these increased risks and others believe that hormones do not play into memory problems at all. After performing our own tests before and after testosterone treatments, we have found that by balancing testosterone levels patients are more able to focus and keep their attention on what they are doing.Growing older is difficult but when you cant remember where you left your keys or stop tasks midway there could be an underlying concern. You should speak with your doctor about your memory loss concerns. Many people brush off memory problems and associate it only with aging. With the knowledge that you could be suffering from another problem that could worsen if left untreated, you should be motivated to seek help for a relief from these upsetting symptoms.&amp;nbsp;

title: Got Moodiness? Let's talk about Benefits of Bio Identical Hormone Replacement Therapy
content: &lt;p style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;The Benefits of Bio identical Hormone Replacement Therapy&lt;/p&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.sottopelletherapy.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/08/mood-swings-unstable-emotions-bpd.jpg&quot;&gt;&lt;/a&gt;As you progress in age, few things may seem like good news when you discuss hormonal changes. By beginning bio identical hormone replacement therapy (BHRT) the benefits may seem endless in comparison. Many of the issues that are commonly associated with getting older often are only symptoms of hormone imbalance. By restoring the balance of your hormones you can eliminate overwhelming symptoms and resume living life and the activities you love.&lt;ul&gt;&lt;li&gt;Increased Energy&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ul&gt;By restoring hormonal balance in your body you can once again experience the energy you used to have. With BHRT, your energy levels can increase substantially allowing you to enjoy activities you had long since given up on because of your lack of vigor.&amp;nbsp;&lt;ul&gt;&lt;li&gt;Enriched Memory and Concentration&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ul&gt;We have heard that growing older means losing your memory. A foggy memory causes frustration and affects every area of your life. By restoring your hormone levels you can improve both your memory and concentration.&amp;nbsp;&lt;ul&gt;&lt;li&gt;Diminished Vaginal Dryness&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ul&gt;Vaginal dryness is caused by low estrogen and high progesterone. By balancing these hormones through BHRT, women can feel rejuvenated once more and be excited again by sex.&amp;nbsp;&lt;ul&gt;&lt;li&gt;Enhanced Mood&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ul&gt;The symptoms you have going through menopause and andropause can have a major impact on your mood and can even lead to depression in some cases. By easing your symptoms through BHRT you will experience a sense of relief and begin to have a more positive outlook now that you are no longer consumed with irritating symptoms.&amp;nbsp;&lt;ul&gt;&lt;li&gt;Improved Libido&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ul&gt;Menopause and andropause causes hormone fluctuations that can lead to a decreased libido. By restoring the hormonal balance, BHRT can help restore the sex drive you used to have.&amp;nbsp;&lt;ul&gt;&lt;li&gt;Decreased Hot Flashes&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ul&gt;Low estrogen is often the main cause of hot flashes is women. Low estrogen has a harsh effect on the hypothalamus, the part of the brain that controls sleep, appetite, sex hormones and temperature. The hypothalamus is deceived by low estrogen levels into believing that the body is too hot and attempts to remedy it by ridding the body of excess heat. By balancing your hormones, you can put an end to hot flashes.&amp;nbsp;&lt;ul&gt;&lt;li&gt;Improved Bone Strength&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ul&gt;Ten million Americans suffer from osteoporosis. Within the five to seven years that follow menopause, a woman can lose up to twenty percent of her bone density. Women who are at risk of osteoporosis can suffer multiple bone fractures due to the lack of bone strength. By restoring their estrogen through BHRT they can repair possible damage and prevent further complications by slowing bone thinning.&amp;nbsp;&lt;ul&gt;&lt;li&gt;Better Muscle Tone&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ul&gt;Through BHRT, there is a decline in muscle fat and an increase in lean body muscle leading to overall enhanced muscle tone and strength. These benefits counteract the symptoms associated with growing older and hormonal imbalance.Schedule an appointment with your doctor to see how BHRT can benefit you!&amp;nbsp;Author: Gino Tutera MD, FACOG, is recognized internationally as a pioneer and leader in the field of bioidentical hormone replacement therapy. He currently is practicing seeing patients for over thirty years and specializing in natural hormone therapy. In 2002, Dr. Tutera founded SottoPelle Therapy. He is the industry leader in recognizing the need for individual and customizable hormone pellet therapy since 1992. Visit www.sottopelletherapy.com for more information or call 480-874-1515

title: Hypothyroidism
content: As you age you may find yourself combated with a number of conditions that worsen as you grow older. A common disorder like this is hypothyroidism. Hypothyroidism symptoms may mimic the symptoms of menopause, particularly relating to muscle strength, memory, and metabolism, the two are often confused but a single solution may not address all ailments.Hypothyroidism is a condition where the thyroid gland is not producing enough of certain important hormones to meet the bodys needs. If hypothyroidism goes untreated, it may result in heart disease, obesity or joint pain. Hypothyroidism often affects women over the age of sixty. If you or a family member have an autoimmune disease or you have undergone radiation therapy you could be at a greater risk for this condition.The symptoms of this condition can often go undetected in the early stages. Dry skin, fatigue, depression, and constipation are common signs. These may lead to unexplained weight gain, muscle weakness, joint pain or stiffness, a slowed heart rate or impaired memory. Testing for hypothyroidism is often done through a blood test and is generally recommended that older women are screened for it routinely.Treating hypothyroidism with a bioidentical hormone replacement therapy (BHRT) such as SottoPelle allows your body to receive the hormones it needs without heavy medications. A medication that specifically addresses the thyroid may be needed in addition to a BHRT but if you are around fifty years old or older, a BHRT may be an excellent option for you as it can treat other symptoms related to menopause or andropause as well as your thyroid condition. If you have concerns about your thyroid, you should speak with your doctor to develop the best course of action for you.Author: Gino Tutera MD, FACOG, is recognized internationally as a pioneer and leader in the field of bio identical hormone replacement therapy. He currently is practicing seeing patients for over thirty years and specializing in natural hormone therapy. In 2002, Dr. Tutera founded SottoPelle Therapy. He is the industry leader in recognizing the need for individual and customizable hormone pellet therapy since 1992. For more information call 480-874-1515

title: Seasonal Mood Disorder
content: &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.sottopelletherapy.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/09/seasonal-affective-disorder-depression.jpg&quot;&gt;&lt;/a&gt;Seasonal Mood and hormonal changes do not discriminate between men and women. Both sexes can suffer from such disorders. It also does not discriminate as to which season to rear its ugly head as it can affect a person in any season, however, many suffer severe depression and other side effects during the winter and summer months. Seasonal mood disorder symptoms and hormonal symptoms can mimic one another.Many people find the hardest season change is from Fall to Winter (known as winter depression) as it is thought that shorter daylight time and less exposure to sunlight are factors along with the change(s) in the weather.Seasonal Mood disorder can affect people in many different ways, from extreme mood changes to depression, difficulty waking in the morning, nausea, lack of energy, feelings of hopelessness, anxiety and lack of interest, to name a few. It may start out mild and increase as time goes on.How does a person know they need to seek treatment for seasonal mood disorder? Ask yourself some of these questions:&lt;ul&gt;&lt;li&gt;Do you find yourself unable to enjoy work or family life?&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Do you have extreme levels of anxiety or depression?&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Are you finding you are experiencing major disruptions in your ability to function, are you eating habits lacking or are your sleep patterns being affected?&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Are you feeling depressed for long periods of time?&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ul&gt;If you have answered yes to any or all of these questions we suggest treating it with a bioidentical hormone replacement therapy (BHRT) such as SottoPelle. A SottoPelle Therapy pellet will allow your body to receive all of the hormones you need to help balance your mood and aid in correcting any symptoms or side effect you may be experiencing from seasonal mood disorder. As always we suggest that you should speak with your doctor first, to help develop the best course of action for you.&amp;nbsp;Author: G&lt;a title=&quot;Gino Tutera MD FACOG&quot; href=&quot;/?page_id=39&quot;&gt;ino Tutera MD, FACOG&lt;/a&gt;, is recognized internationally as a pioneer and leader in the field of bio identical hormone replacement therapy. title: A Recent Study Finds HRT for Postmenopausal Women May Decrease the Risk of Pancreatic Cancer...
content: &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.sottopelletherapy.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/09/PELLET-WITH-VIAL.jpg&quot;&gt;&lt;/a&gt;A recent study found that one type of hormone replacement therapy (HRT) for postmenopausal women may decrease the risk of pancreatic cancer. In the study, women from California who took estrogen-only HRT for symptoms of menopause were 41 percent less likely to develop pancreatic cancer over a 14-year period than women who never took hormone replacement therapy.Generally, estrogen-only hormone therapy is only provided to women who have had their uterus removed, therefore, most therapies have a combination of hormones including ones like progestin. The study found associations, and cannot prove that estrogen in hormone replacement therapy actually causes an increase or decrease inpancreatic cancer risk. In addition, pancreatic cancer is rare, so the risk of any woman in the study developing the condition was small.&lt;b&gt;About the Study: &lt;/b&gt;The new study involved more than 118,000 female public school professionals in California who were surveyed in 1995 to 1996 about their use of hormone replacement therapy and current or past use of oral contraceptives, and were followed until 2009. At the start of the study, 60 percent of the women were postmenopausal, 25 percent of whom were current users of estrogen-only HRT, and 33 percent of whom were current users of estrogen-plus-progestin HRT. During the study period, 323 women (0.27 percent) were diagnosed with pancreatic cancer. The study, conducted by researchers at the University of Southern California, was published online Sept. 5 in the journal American Journal of Epidemiology.&lt;b&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;b&gt;Blog Author:&lt;/b&gt; &lt;a title=&quot;Gino Tutera MD FACOG&quot; href=&quot;/?page_id=39&quot;&gt;Gino Tutera MD, FACOG&lt;/a&gt;, is recognized internationally as a pioneer and leader in the field of&lt;a title=&quot;What is Hormone Replacement Therapy?&quot; href=&quot;/?page_id=260&quot;&gt; bio identical hormone replacement therapy&lt;/a&gt;. He currently is practicing seeing patients for over thirty years and specializing in natural hormone therapy. In 2002, Dr. Tutera founded SottoPelle Therapy. He is the industry leader in recognizing the need for individual and customizable hormone pellet therapy since 1992. title: Fear of Hormone Replacement Therapy – Don’t let it Stop You!
content: &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.sottopelletherapy.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/09/images.jpg&quot;&gt;&lt;/a&gt;The words &lt;a title=&quot;What is Hormone Replacement Therapy?&quot; href=&quot;/?page_id=260&quot;&gt;hormone replacement therapy&lt;/a&gt; unfortunately scares people with negative news media releasing information about pharmacies or botched therapies. It is absolutely critical to understand that the correct Pellet Hormone Replacement Therapy is not about synthetic pharmaceuticals it should be about two critical hormones in our body. Estrogen and testosterone are 100 percent identical to those created by the human body. When you are using a board certified doctor or physician, you can be assured that the Pellet HRT is made from botanicals but also precisely matches the molecular structure of your human hormone.For decades &lt;a title=&quot;Hormone Replacement Therapy for Men&quot; href=&quot;/?page_id=264&quot;&gt;men&lt;/a&gt; and &lt;a title=&quot;Hormone Replacement Therapy for Women&quot; href=&quot;/?page_id=262&quot;&gt;women&lt;/a&gt; have experienced the astounding benefits of pellet hormone replacement therapy. In study after study, researchers have reported how the use of biologically identical estrogen and testosterone in bio-identical pellet hormone replacement therapy has positively impacted diseases such as osteoporosis, prostate cancer and HIV.How can you make sure you are working with a professional when seeking Pellet Hormone Replacement Therapy?&lt;ol&gt;&lt;li&gt;Ask questions are they a medical doctor? You would be surprised the number of groups that are not medical doctors who are doing this type of work.&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Ask about the compounding pharmacy they use SottoPelle has been using the same pharmacy for decades. Unfortunately many new groups were formed that were not as advanced or medically sound. Make sure you ask about the pharmacy.&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Request information about speaking to a patient that has been doing Pellet Hormone Replacement Therapy. We know at our office there are hundreds of thrilled patients that would speak about their experience.&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Stay off of Google the worst place to find accurate medical information or advice is on Google. The problem is most people dont know what they are searching for and you will always find bad news most of which probably isnt true.&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Know that Estradiol and Testosterone have been regulated by the FDA for Human Use.&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Research options Pellet Therapy doesnt include creams or shots for an individual and each lot of hormone pellets contains pure hormone (99.89%) and a human fatty acid (0.2%) to bind them together (unlike other pellets that use synthetic fillers). The hormones are individually pressed or fused into very small solid cylinders or pellets. Estradiol pellets are a little bigger than a grain of riceapproximately 3 millimeters in diameter. Testosterone pellets are a bit larger than estradiol pellets at 4.5mm.&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ol&gt;Any reputable and professional medical professional will answer your questions and concerns make sure you are shopping around for a Doctor that has years of experience and history in HRT. Cheaper doesnt always mean better; experience is a must when dealing with your hormones. The reality is that today you can stop the troubling symptoms of hormone imbalance and begin to feel better with Pellet Hormone Replacement Therapy. Dont let your fears stop you follow our step-by-step question guide to bring you peace of mind.&lt;b&gt;Blog Author:&lt;/b&gt; Gino Tutera MD, FACOG, is recognized internationally as a pioneer and leader in the field of bio identical hormone replacement therapy. title: The Hormone Hoax Thousands Fall For
content: &lt;p style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.sottopelletherapy.com/articles/More_Magazine_Hormone_Hoax.pdf&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;(Click to Read Article)&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;h4 style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;More Magazine - The Hormone Hoax Thousands Fall For&lt;/h4&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;h2&gt;Dr. Tuteras Response:&lt;/h2&gt;After reading the article &lt;i&gt;The Hormone Hoax&lt;/i&gt;, I felt compelled to comment on the subject.I did not see any disclaimer that the author received no financial benefit or subsidy, directly or indirectly, from any pharmaceutical company.Because the content of the article was definitely biased toward the pharmaceutical industry, and unless the author discloses whether she received directly or indirectly, any support from the pharmaceutical industry, the article is worthless in its content.A number of the clinicians quoted do have ties to the pharmaceutical industry and naturally would espouse these opinions in support of the products produced by the pharmaceutical industry.In an effort to be fair, I do agree that the manner in which hormone replacement is done is and always has been archaic and unscientific.Whether bio-identical or synthetic, patients are not given doses that are individualized for that patients particular needs.By not individualizing the dose for each patient, it would be impossible to achieve the appropriate physiologic effect to benefit that particular patient.To properly calculate the dosage necessary for each male or female patient, a number of factors need to be taken into consideration.But physicians are never trained to do anything more than use a standard starting dose, chosen arbitrarily, and then give more or less hormone depending on the symptoms.Using this approach I ask, Where is the science? This method of dosing hormone is without scientific basis, whether using biologically identical or synthetic hormones.The primary issue featured in the article is what biologically identical truly means.The only parameter the author focuses on is the biochemical structure.Biologically identical should only be attached to hormone replacement that satisfies the following parameters:1)A hormone that has the exact biochemical structure as the human hormone2)The hormone or hormones need to be replaced in the exact ratio in which the body produces the hormone to effect the maximum physiologic protection, (i.e., Estradiol to Estrone ratio of 2:1) the ratio the human body produces during the female luteal phase, which is the time a woman is in her most protected state.)3)The dose of hormone has to be dosed exactly for each patient, utilizing a dosing formula to produce a normal level of hormone that would be biologically identical for each patient and be protective.4)Most importantly, the hormone therapy cannot be biologically identical unless the delivery system utilized replicates the secretion pattern of the organ being replicated (i.e., ovary or testicle).Without fulfilling these parameters, the term biologically identical cannot be attached to a product.Which brings me to the appalling statement contained in the article that pellet therapy is dangerous and the example used is a group of medical clinics that were using an excellent therapy in a very incorrect manner. They were not properly supervised and they misused pellets.Would you term robotic surgery dangerous because a certain surgeon misused it, which resulted in serious complications?The answer is NO! The modality is good, the user was poorly trained.To state that pellets are dangerous demonstrates a lack of knowledge and research on the part of the author and her expert. The clinics referenced violated every standard of medical care and dosed everyone incorrectly.The clinic was incorrectly using an excellent form of hormone replacement, which became a recipe for disaster.In fact, pellet hormone replacement in contrast to the authors belief and expert opinion, is one of the most researched forms of hormone delivery, starting in 1939 by Dr. R. Greenblatt from the University of Georgia Medical College. And the clinics he established have been using pellet therapy continuously since 1937. Researchers such as Susan Davis MD, Margaret Thom MD, J. W. W. Studd, Dr. Craviato, Dr. D. Gambrell, Dr. Natrajan, Dr. Davelaar and Dr. Morris Notelovitz, all attest to the safety and efficacy of pellet hormone replacement with its ability to lower cholesterol, elevate HDL, normalize carbohydrate and insulin metabolism, reduce insulin resistance, improve myocardial function, reverse osteopenia and osteoporosis and proof that the use of pellet hormone replacement does not increase the incidence of the development of breast cancer.In fact, in our SottoPelle clinics, our incidence of breast cancer is 1:1000, compared to a 1:9for women not using hormones.The SottoPelle clinics and their doctors are strictly trained to use a proprietary, patent-pending formula to individualize the dose of estradiol and testosterone for each patient to effect a physiologic level of estradiol and testosterone for that particular patient. Our clinics are the only pellet replacement clinics that use this unique formula.Pellet hormone therapy is the only form of hormone replacement that satisfies all the parameters previously mentioned.1)SottoPelle Therapy correctly uses pellets that are manufactured to only contain estradiol and testosterone that are biologically identical in structure and are analyzed by an outside pharmacological lab for potency, purity, sterility and proper dissolution.2)The pellets are the only form of hormone replacement, which when properly dosed, replicates the protective ratio of estradiol to estrone ratio of 2:1 (Margaret Thom, MD 1983).3)The dosage has to be individualized to produce the physiologic levels of estradiol and testosterone necessary to produce the beneficial effects on the central nervous systems, cardiovascular system, musculoskeletal system, and produce metabolic normality, only seen with pellets.4)The pellets are the only form of hormone delivery to reproduce the secretion pattern of the ovary and testicle.The pellets release of hormone is governed and controlled by heart rate and cardiac output, therefore, as long as the patients heart is beating and has a piece of a pellet in place, the secretion of hormone is continuous and will vary according to the patients needs.The body, therefore, controls the continuous release of the hormone, thereby allowing the body to increase or decrease the amount of hormone released, according to the bodys needs. No other form of hormone delivery (i.e., pills, patches, creams and gels, suppositories, rings or shots) allows the body to control the release of the hormone. Without the internal control of hormone release, the patient does not get a biologically identical secretion of hormone as with pellets.Without the continuous secretion of hormone, you cannot get the beneficial effect of the hormone and pellets are the only form of hormone delivery that delivers hormone in a biologically identical manner.In conclusion, pellet hormone replacement is the only true, biologically identical hormone replacement and according to the literature and the results seen in the tens of thousands of patients, both male and female, treated in our clinics over the past 22 years, is the only truly protective form of biologically identical hormone and is not dangerous.&amp;nbsp;Gino Tutera, MD, FACOG

title: A Strong Case for Hormone Replacement
content: &lt;b&gt;&lt;i&gt;HORMONE REPLACEMENT THERAPY&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/b&gt;Endocrine hormones are vital to health and well-being. It is critical that these chemicals exist in balance in order to perform as they are intended to. Without question, living with abnormally low levels of hormones, as occurs in menopause or andropause, upsets that balance and sends an open invitation to the physical, emotional and mental decline of aging and the chronic diseases that accompany it.The case for hormone replacement is compelling. Unlike the early days when HRT was basically an experiment designed to reduce menopause symptoms and backed by pharmaceutical marketing campaigns rather than long term studies, recent research is redefining the present-day approach.A large body of scientific evidence already exists substantiating the effects (both positive and negative) of todays HRT modalities. This important data will continue to accrue as current investigative outcomes are evaluated and more studies are undertaken.Many practitioners now recognize menopause and andropause for what they are&lt;i&gt;wellness issues&lt;/i&gt;, and employ modalities that go beyond simply relieving symptoms. This more enlightened approach will help millions of peoplethose who wish to live longer and stay healthier as they ageto make better health choices.&lt;b&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;b&gt;THE STRONG CASE FOR HORMONE REPLACEMENT &lt;/b&gt;Endocrine hormones serve as the powerful chemical messengers that keep the body running in tiptop shape. They flow through the bloodstream around the clock, traveling to specific cells in order to orchestrate many of the bodys internal functions, including the behavior of vital organs. Even a small fluctuation in levels can cause big changes in cells or disturb the balance throughout the entire body. Too much or too little of a hormone can have someone suffering serious consequences.This is why the hormone deficiencies associated with menopause and andropause are so disruptive to a persons health. As hormone production subsides, a person is literally &lt;i&gt;wasting away on the inside&lt;/i&gt;becoming frailer, losing muscle and bone mass, developing clogged arteries and losing mental acuity. The quality of life plummets at the same time the risk for many degenerative diseases skyrockets.Noted physicians Erika Schwartz and Kent Holtorf, published a seminal review of literature in 2008. In their article, they surveyed the outcomes of 267 studies which addressed the safety and efficacy aspects of various hormone replacement therapies. Their research literature was dated as far back as 1941 and centered on subjects ranging from the role played by conjugated and synthetic hormones in the increased risk of various types of cancer, to the positive impact of restored estradiol and testosterone levels on osteoporosis and cardiovascular disease when using bio-identicals. At end, Schwartz and Holtorf concluded unequivocally that hormone replacement has indeed been shown to be &lt;i&gt;an important tool in wellness and prevention&lt;/i&gt;. Additionally, they found that &lt;i&gt;the type of hormone therapies&lt;/i&gt; &lt;i&gt;chosen&lt;/i&gt; &lt;i&gt;for patients is what makes the difference and must be carefully considered&lt;/i&gt;.&lt;a title=&quot;&quot; href=&quot;file:///C:/Users/shamburger/AppData/Local/Microsoft/Windows/Temporary%20Internet%20Files/Content.Outlook/S90KZP02/HORMONE%20REPLACEMENT%20THERAPY_Tutera_062513.docx#_ftn1&quot;&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;b&gt;THE CONTROVERSY&lt;/b&gt;Its true that widespread disparity exists between hormone replacement physicians as to which hormones are the most important to replenish. If youve ever done an Internet search on the topic, you likely came up with no less than MILLIONS of websites suggesting a variety of solutions. These websites represent a wide range of opinions and endorsements; everything from organizations, medical groups and drug companies to HRT physicians, insurance companies and even celebrities. Youll find some recommending estrone or progesterone replacement as the panacea; others say its your DHEA, pregnenalone or human growth hormone (HGH) that need restoring; while still others prescribe testosterone and any or all of the three estrogens. And then there are the proponents of soy and herbals and so on. When so many are offering such varied solutions, its hard to imagine how patients can make sense of it.Bottom linethere really isnt an across the board consensus in the medical community, and despite the building evidence on bio-identicals and the importance of using the proper delivery method, there probably wont be for some time. However, there is a certain level of agreement since the most common replacement today generally consists of some form of estrogen combined with some form of progesterone. Testosterone is also at times included.&lt;b&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;b&gt;THE KEY IS HORMONAL BALANCE&lt;/b&gt;Hormone replacement is complex, especially when the desired outcome is a return to homeostasis. You cannot randomly take any hormone or substance in any amount and expect to achieve hormonal balance. In order to regain this internal state, the method must be precise, available 24/7 and based on replacing the essential missing hormones with those that are biologically identical.That perfectly describes the basis of &lt;a title=&quot;Our Method&quot; href=&quot;/?page_id=42&quot;&gt;SottoPelle therapy&lt;/a&gt;.&amp;nbsp;&lt;div&gt;&lt;br clear=&quot;all&quot; /&gt;&lt;hr align=&quot;left&quot; size=&quot;1&quot; width=&quot;33%&quot; /&gt;&lt;div&gt;&lt;a title=&quot;&quot; href=&quot;file:///C:/Users/shamburger/AppData/Local/Microsoft/Windows/Temporary%20Internet%20Files/Content.Outlook/S90KZP02/HORMONE%20REPLACEMENT%20THERAPY_Tutera_062513.docx#_ftnref1&quot;&gt;&lt;/a&gt; Schwartz, E; Holtorf K (2008). Hormones in Wellness and Disease Prevention: Common Practices, Current State of the Evidence, and Questions for the Future. &lt;i&gt;Prim Care Clin Office Pract&lt;/i&gt; &lt;b&gt;35&lt;/b&gt; (4): 669705.&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/div&gt;

title: Breast Cancer. Simply Hearing the Words can Spark a Range of Emotions.
content: &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.sottopelletherapy.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/10/BCR-Pink-Ribbon.jpg&quot;&gt;&lt;/a&gt;Breast cancer. Simply hearing the words can spark a range of emotions, especially if your life or the life of someone you love has been changed by this all-too-common disease. According to the National Institutes of Health, one in eight women will be affected in their lifetime. Breast Cancer kills more women in the United States than any other cancer except lung cancer and the older a woman gets, the higher her risk of developing breast cancer. Those are sobering statistics, to be sure and to Dr. Gino Tutera, they are a call to action.&amp;nbsp;Dr. Tutera is not only a respected physician, but a pioneer in the field of bioidentical hormone replacement therapy (BHRT). He developed SottoPelle, a revolutionary method of delivering precisely the right balance of hormones when the body needs them most. And as a doctor who has tested the hormone levels of a countless number of patients, he knows a correlation when he sees one. Around age forty, there is an increase in fibrocystic disease of the breast, Dr. Tutera says. It coincides with women losing fifty percent of their testosterone production.&amp;nbsp;Testosterone, long thought of as a mens hormone, is equally important to women in maintaining normal physiology. In fact, pre-menopausal women produce 300 milligrams of testosterone per day: a bucketful as opposed to a thimbleful. Still, says Dr. Tutera, it has been uniformly ignored. But for women at risk for or suffering from breast cancer, a restoration of normal testosterone levels can produce results that are nothing short of miraculous.&amp;nbsp;Testosterone therapy helps decrease over-activity of cells in the breast, Dr. Tutera asserts. And if you decrease cell proliferation, you cut down on the occurrence of cystic disease. But if you think thats all testosterone replacement therapy can do, think again: this powerhouse also maintains bone density and prevents muscle loss, decreases cholesterol and triglycerides, lowers high blood pressure and decreases the risk of heart disease, and helps to provide an overall sense of wellbeing. Whats more, testosterone stimulates receptor sites in the parietal, temporal, and frontal lobes of the brain to stave off dementia and decrease the chances of developing Alzheimers disease. The proper level of testosterone benefits anyone, and can be a literal lifesaver for breast cancer patients who see not only a higher level of survivability, but a lower chance of recurrence.&amp;nbsp;Breast cancer patients are uniformly subjected to the usual treatment of no hormones whatsoever, which actually shortens the life span, says Dr. Tutera. Through testosterone replacement with SottoPelle, we have the capability to help patients get their quality of life back. SottoPelle uses pellets that are comprised of the highest quality botanical ingredients, formulated to precisely match the hormones which naturally occur in the body, with no unnecessary fillers or artificial ingredients to hinder the assimilation process. This fully customized form of BHRT delivers the exact dosage of hormones that the body needs, efficiently recreating the natural physiological balance.&amp;nbsp;No one wants to be the one woman in eight who is affected by breast cancer and certainly not more than once. Could testosterone replacement therapy with SottoPelle be the protection you need?&amp;nbsp;&lt;b&gt;Blog Author:&lt;/b&gt; Gino Tutera MD, FACOG, is recognized internationally as a pioneer and leader in the field of bio identical hormone replacement therapy. He currently is practicing seeing patients for over thirty years and specializing in natural hormone therapy. In 2002, Dr. Tutera founded SottoPelle Therapy. He is the pioneer and industry leader in recognizing the need for individual and customizable hormone pellet therapy since 1992. title: The thyroid gland is a small organ within the endocrine system.
content: &lt;p style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.sottopelletherapy.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/10/download.jpg&quot;&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;The thyroid gland is a small organ within the endocrine system. It weighs a merely 20 grams, or less than an ounce, and it is found in the neck beneath the Adams Apple. Despite its small size, it is one of the most important hormone-secreting organs in the body. Your thyroid provides a vital hormone to maintain and function the entire body. When this vital hormone is deficient, even in small amounts, it often results in a multitude of symptoms and conditions affecting every organ in your body.&amp;nbsp;One of the important organs in the body that often undergoes changes before, during and after menopause is the thyroid gland. In fact, studies show that hypothyroidism is far more common in women, especially women of menopausal age or who has a family history of hypothyroidism. The following are a few basic facts about hypothyroidism: Hypothyroidism affects 20 million Americans, or 1 in every 10 people. Hypothyroidism runs in families, specifically among other females in the family such as a mother, aunt, grandmother, or sister. Surveys demonstrate that hypothyroidism is up to 8x more common in women than men. By the time a woman is age 50, 1 out of every 10 to 12 women has some level of hypothyroidism and by age 60, it is as common as 1 out of every 5 or 6 women.&amp;nbsp;The following list of symptoms is consistent with hypothyroidism. If you are suffering from any of these, please speak with your family physician regarding treatment. (These are only a few of the most common symptoms). Weakness Fatigue Constipation Weight gain Depression Paleness Dry flaky skin Hoarseness Abnormal menstrual periods Muscle pain Thin brittle hair and fingernails&amp;nbsp;There are several blood tests that can be performed to accurately assess thyroid function. If your physician is attempting to determine your thyroid status, the blood test panel should consist of the following: TSH Thyroid Stimulating Hormone Total T 4 or T4 Total T3 Free T4 Free T3 Anti-TPO and Anti-Tg Antibodies&amp;nbsp;If your healthcare provider has determined that you present clinically with hypothyroidism, a likely course of action will be to offer thyroid &lt;a title=&quot;Hormone Replacement Therapy&quot; href=&quot;/?page_id=2&quot;&gt;hormone replacement therapy&lt;/a&gt;. There are many options you should carefully explore both through your own research and with your doctor.&amp;nbsp;&lt;b&gt;Blog Author:&lt;/b&gt; &lt;a title=&quot;Gino Tutera MD FACOG&quot; href=&quot;/?page_id=39&quot;&gt;Gino Tutera MD, FACOG&lt;/a&gt;, is recognized internationally as a pioneer and leader in the field of bio identical hormone replacement therapy. He currently is practicing seeing patients for over thirty years and specializing in natural hormone therapy. In 2002, Dr. Tutera founded SottoPelle Therapy. He is the pioneer and industry leader in recognizing the need for individual and customizable hormone pellet therapy since 1992. Visit &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.sottopelletherapy.com/&quot;&gt;www.sottopelletherapy.com&lt;/a&gt; for more information or call 480-874-1515.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;

title: What age did you find yourself coming into Menopause?
content: &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.sottopelletherapy.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/10/healthy-eating-final3.jpg&quot;&gt;&lt;/a&gt;Fact: Every woman is going to go through menopause. Women can begin experiencing symptoms anywhere between the ages of 39 to 51 and they can last for at least 5&lt;b&gt;&lt;i&gt; &lt;/i&gt;&lt;/b&gt;to 20 years. We all know the most common symptoms are night sweats, mood swings, weight gain, sleepless nights, hot flashes, etc. But what can we do to help lessen our symptoms with hopes to feel complete again?Our focus for this blog is to take a look at your daily lifestyle and what you are eating as many women do not pay enough attention to these areas.We have provided you with a list of some of the foods that will relieve and/or lessen symptoms:&lt;ol&gt;&lt;li&gt;Eat Calcium rich foods such as yogurt, low fat milk, cheese, sardines, spinach, kale and shrimp. Consuming more calcium will help prevent osteoporosis too!&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Omega 3 fatty acid rich foods such as walnuts, walnut oil, canola oil, olive oil, tuna fish, Salmon and Mackerel and avocado. Meals and snacks loaded with Omega 3 can help reduce the side effect of night sweats.&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Soy products can relieve hot flashes and night sweats and we suggest tofu, soy beans, soy milk and edamame.&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Vitamin B rich foods to include in your diet are spinach, fish, broccoli, lean meat or poultry, tomatoes and potatoes.&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;We also recommend consuming many fruits and vegetables throughout the day, paying special attention to incorporate them into your main breakfast, lunch and dinner menus.&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ol&gt;&amp;nbsp;We must also remember that menopause is not an illness and there ARE SOLUTIONS to the treating the symptoms. If you have any questions or concerns we always recommend you visit with your physician or a specialist. Always check with your doctor before starting or stopping a particular diet.Eat, drink and stay healthy!&amp;nbsp;&lt;b&gt;Blog Author:&lt;/b&gt; Gino Tutera MD, FACOG, is recognized internationally as a pioneer and leader in the field of bio identical hormone replacement therapy. He currently is practicing seeing patients for over thirty years and specializing in natural hormone therapy. In 2002, Dr. Tutera founded SottoPelle Therapy. title: Response by Gino Tutera MD, FACOG to an article in regards to “low-T?” Testosterone therapy and heart troubles.
content: &lt;p style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.sottopelletherapy.com/articles/testosterone-heart-risks.pdf&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;(Click to Read Article)&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;Once again the medical researchers and the media have muddled the picture for hormone replacement. A recently published study from JAMA has been misinterpreted by the researchers and the media. They state the use of testosterone in men with significant heart disease increased the chance of heart attack and stroke by 26%, but the media failed to point out that the group of men in the study who did not have testosterone, had a 20% increase in heart attack and stroke therefore the true increase was only 6% not 26%. Unfortunately, the health of these men was poor. All of them had significant cardiac disease, diabetes, hypertension, and significant smoking history.This study was doomed from the start since the researchers only used the synthetic testosterone which has been shown to cause cardiac muscle abnormalities as well as vasospasm and vasoconstriction in the coronary arteries which undoubtedly would show an increase in heart attack and stroke, especially in this very sick population of men.As with the WHI in women, the study does not differentiate between the types of testosterone used, or the dosage given. The results were also skewed from the start by the sickness of the study group. In the literature, if the patient is given aromatizable testosterone, which acts like human testosterone, it results in dilatation of the coronary arteries as well as decreasing the total cholesterol and ldl in patients (Tenover, js ,J. Clin. Endo.Metab 1992, Wus.,Weng x, 1992 Chin Med Sci, Hamm, l. J.Clin. Endo. 1942, lesser ma, J.Clin. Endo. 1946 , Simon D. J. Clin. Endo. Metab. 1997 ). Common sense tells you that if men derive adverse effects from testosterone, then we should be seeing heart disease, stroke, and cardiac deaths in 30 year old men who carry the highest testosterone, but the opposite is true.If men would receive the identical testosterone that they make, then the protective effects would be restored. I have treated men for over 20 years with bio identical testosterone delivered by subcutaneous pellets and have only seen the beneficial effects of improved lipid parameters, increased exercise tolerance, improved mental skills and memory, better muscle mass, and greater quality of life. The patients I have treated with significant heart disease are still thriving and lead a healthy productive life.If there is anything to be taken away from this flawed study it is that we need to fund a study in which synthetic testosterone is compared to bio identical testosterone in a manner in which the patient receives individualized dosing according to calculations of certain variables such as age and physical size and others. Then and only then, will the medical community and the general population finally know that the use of biologically identical testosterone is the best and safest method of testosterone replacement.

title: Don’t Overheat this Holiday Season
content: &lt;p style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.sottopelletherapy.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/11/menopause-funny.jpg&quot;&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;This third article in our Hormones and Holidays series of blogs will focus on an issue so many women struggle with Menopause. Bio-Identical Hormone Pellet Therapy, The SottoPelle Method is the superior choice for any menopause symptoms. Peri-menopause typically begins when a woman is in her 40s and can average 4 to 8 years. Menopause occurs roughly in women their early 50s. Every year it is estimated that 1.3 million women are expected to reach menopause. Menopause is more than just a list of symptoms (though we outline symptoms below)or not having a period for a year. The clinical definition that SottoPelle uses for diagnosis is quite simply stated: A woman is in menopause when the level of follicle stimulating hormone (FSH), a pituitary hormone, reaches and stays above a level greater than 23 miu/ml whether she is menstruating or not menstruating.&amp;nbsp;Watch for these signs this Holiday Season.&lt;b&gt;Signs and Symptoms of Menopause:&lt;/b&gt;&lt;ul&gt;&lt;li&gt;Hot flashes&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Severe sweating can happen both day and night&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Insomnia&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Vaginal dryness&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Vaginal discomfort&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Irritability&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Loss of memory or fuzzy thinking&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Cold sweats&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Irregular periods&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Anxiety&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Mood swings&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Headaches&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Sadness&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ul&gt;Dont let Menopause ruin your holidays. title: Calling all Men – Fear not for seeking help with your hormones during the holidays.
content: Our fourth article in our hormone and holidays series focuses on men. Often, during a hectic holiday season, men will suffer in silence with baffling symptoms they dont understand. As men age, certain symptoms may be signs of hormone imbalance due to andropause. Its important to remind men that they can seek help and that Bio-Identical Hormone Pellet Therapy, The SottoPelle Method can help them.The following are six common signs we have visited before on our Blog but a reminder is so crucial during the chaotic days and nights over the Holidays. The below could indicate a hormonal deficiency.1. &lt;b&gt;Thinning of Hair &amp;amp; Loss of Body Hair&lt;/b&gt;Decreased testosterone levels leads to loss of scalp and body hair because an imbalance of testosterone to Dihydrotestosterone (DHT) exists. DHT inhibits the growth of new hair cells and hair cells are not replaced after they fall out when DHT activity is higher than testosterone activity.2. &lt;b&gt;Weight Gain&lt;/b&gt;Weight gain is commonly reported by men during andropause. The decrease in testosterone levels leads to higher insulin and cortisol levels. When men have high cortisol levels, their bodies can increase the production of fat cells and increases appetite. High levels of insulin and cortisol also decreases metabolism and continues to decrease testosterone. The combination of these effects leads to weight gain.3. &lt;b&gt;Decreased Libido&lt;/b&gt;As energy decreases with lower testosterone levels, mens sex drive often follows. The libido is considered highly dependent on hormone levels and is affected by the changes in hormones as men enter andropause. The loss of energy and strength during this time in a mans life also plays into a lowered libido, as does less stimulation of the libido center in the brain.4. &lt;b&gt;Trouble sleeping&lt;/b&gt;Low testosterone and heightened cortisol levels can lead to sleep apnea. Because human growth hormones are made during the first ninety minutes of sleep, interrupted sleep leads to the disruption of hormone production. When sleep is interrupted it can lead to worsened fatigue and insomnia, as well as, reduce insulin sensitivity.5. &lt;b&gt;Depression&lt;/b&gt;Depression is a common side effect of decreased testosterone. Decreased testosterone leads to lower serotonin levels in the brain. Often times, men are not accustomed to being vocal about their emotions, but it is important for them to share these feelings with a medical professional as it may be a symptom of low testosterone.6. &lt;b&gt;Muscle Loss&lt;/b&gt;Testosterone is a major component in the production of strong muscles in men. As the testosterone decreases in men, their muscle strength can also decrease as they lose energy and their bodies begin turning muscle fibers into fat.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Remember: Dont &lt;b&gt;&lt;i&gt;try to &lt;/i&gt;&lt;/b&gt;fight these symptoms yourself. The great gift of the &lt;b&gt;SottoPelle Therapy&lt;/b&gt; can have you on your way to looking and feeling young again. You deserve to get the most out of life and enjoy your Holidays.&amp;nbsp;&lt;b&gt;Blog Author:&lt;/b&gt; Gino Tutera MD, FACOG, is recognized internationally as a pioneer and leader in the field of bio identical hormone replacement therapy and a published author of three books and articles in medical journals. He currently is practicing seeing patients for over thirty years and specializing in natural hormone therapy. In 2002, Dr. Tutera founded SottoPelle Therapy. He is the pioneer and industry leader in recognizing the need for individual and customizable hormone pellet therapy since 1992.
