title: Goblins, Ghouls and Hormones, Oh My!
content: &lt;strong&gt;The real truth about Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT)&lt;/strong&gt;Are you spooked by recent reports citing the supposed dangers of hormone therapy? Dont be tricked by all the confusing or conflicting articles that will not only scare the dickens out of you, but also fail to distinguish between the two very different types of hormones the safe kind and the harmful variety. In fact, weve got a treat in store for you with some good news about why the right dose of beneficial hormones can actually help women, and not harm them.The array of alarming hormone reports online and in print are often scary and widely accepted as the gospel truth, but many of the things written are out of context or not based on all the facts.Like scenes from a cult horror flick, these reports continue like bad sequels featuring the same familiar demons from years ago. The Womens Health Initiative (WHI) issued its first report on the dangers of synthetic hormone therapy a long time ago. Now this ghost haunts us once again as the outdated scare script rears its ugly head this month with yet another claim about the health hazards of hormone therapy.What these reports fail to ever mention is that there are TWO COMPLETELY DIFFERENT types of hormone therapies the natural bio-identical kind (BHRT) and the synthetic pharmaceutical type (HRT) symptoms.Think of it like the two witches in the Wizard of Oz the wicked one being the hazardous hormones and then theres the good witch, the bio-identical benefactor. With the wave of a wand, one can threaten your well-being while the other can bestow health blessings.Seems simple enough, but why dont more people understand or explain this basic difference?Due to the lack in patient education on the hormone facts, were stepping up this Halloween to set the record straight and put these ghosts to rest. Well also give you a goodie for your hormone trick or treat bag because we believe women dont need to be scared just informed.Keep in mind that most articles and blogs are usually focused on the synthetic hormones (HRT) the bad witch and will try to spook you -- but weve got your back. The fact is that bio-identical hormones (BHRT) the good witch is perfectly safe without any of the harmful side effects associated with the synthetic hormones in the WHI report.So, yes, the WHI is right in that synthetic hormones are harmful for you. They just forgot to mention the potential benefits of the natural bio-identical ones that are backed by scientific studies showing their safety and effectiveness.Consequently, a well-researched report in &lt;em&gt;The New York Times&lt;/em&gt;, Avoiding Estrogen Therapy Proved Deadly for Nearly 50,000 Women, echoes Dr. Tuteras longtime concerns. The article notes that according to a report in the &lt;em&gt;American Journal of Public Health&lt;/em&gt; by researchers at the Yale School of Medicine, the widespread rejection of allhormone replacement therapies among menopausal women has been misguided since the WHI warnings against HRT were issued in 2002.In other words, since all forms of hormone therapy were improperly condemned as harmful due to the earlier WHI findings, an estimated 50,000 women died prematurely from 2002-2009 because they did not use estrogen after hysterectomies. Could BHRT have saved some lives? We also wonder how many uncounted women suffered from heart attacks, dementia, and other ailments associated with lack of estrogen.While thats a scary statistic, SottoPelle has some reassuring information for you.BHRTs potential benefits are now documented in Dr. Tuteras 10-year study titled Marked reduction of breast, endometrial and ovarian cancer in users of bio-identical estradiol and testosterone subcutaneous pellets. The results have been published in two prestigious medical publications &lt;em&gt;SEMAL&lt;/em&gt;, an international anti-aging medical journal , and &lt;em&gt;Maturitas&lt;/em&gt;, a U.S. peer-reviewed scientific journal in 2009. This research shows that his pellet method of estradiol and testosterone therapy offers protection against the development of several forms of cancer.We think thats not only exciting news, but worthy of worldwide headlines.In his study, Dr. Tutera concludes:&lt;em&gt;The Womens Health Initiative incorrectly implied that all estrogen increases the development of breast cancer after three years. This inaccurate assumption prompted women to discontinue all forms of hormone therapy and suffer the ravages of menopause and possibly increase their risk of heart disease, osteoporosis, dementia and many other diseases. &lt;/em&gt;&lt;em&gt;The present retrospective study was done to prove that the usage of bio-identical estradiol, testosterone and micronized progesterone did not increase the incidence of breast, endometrial and ovarian cancer. The study affirmed that the re-creation of the normal physiologic hormonal environment through the usage of subcutaneous estradiol and testosterone pellets imparts a protective effect against the development of breast, endometrial and ovarian cancer.&lt;/em&gt;&lt;em&gt;Furthermore, the usage of subcutaneous estradiol and testosterone pellets should be encouraged because of the positive effects seen on bone density , the lack of adverse impact on serum lipids, the lack of adverse effect on cardiovascular health and superior control of the symptoms associated with the menopause.&lt;/em&gt;Adding more goblins to the hormone scare is another report issued this month by The Endocrine Society with its clinical guidelines for androgen therapy in women, claiming that there is insufficient research or evidence to demonstrate the effectiveness of testosterone therapy. Huh? More hormone horrors? Tell that to the thousands of female SottoPelle patients thriving on testosterone around the globe.In response, Dr. Tutera provides the following facts backed by their accompanying studies:&lt;em&gt;Once again we are being misled; the lack of knowledge about the young females need for testosterone is a physiologic fact. The daily production of testosterone by premenopausal women from ovarian and adrenal sources is 300 mg daily, not weekly or annually (Abraham et al J Clin Endo Metab.1974:39:340-346). The assays that we are all using do not reflect this value. In fact &lt;strong&gt;all of the assays have been shown to be inaccurate, unreliable, and insensitive &lt;/strong&gt;and only have value in assessing the male patient as they lose their accuracy below a level of 300 ng/dL. (Lobo et al Fert Sterility, 2004 :44,&amp;amp; Clinical Chemistry 2005). J W W Studd stated in his work published in Meno Intl., 2010, that premenopausal women carry testosterone levels ten times the level of estrogen. Furthermore, the majority of testosterone loss occurs in the early reproductive years (Davison et al J Clin Endo Metab 2005:90:3847-3853), and that &lt;strong&gt;by age 40 normal premenopausal women have lost at least half of their testosterone production&lt;/strong&gt; (Zumoff et al J Clin Endo Metab1995: 80:1429-1430).&lt;/em&gt;&lt;em&gt;Why then are we being told that the use of testosterone is only for hypoactive sexual disorder when in fact &lt;strong&gt;denying young women this important hormone increases the risk of bone loss, muscle loss, loss of function in the parietal, temporal and frontal lobes of the brain, and finally loss of normal metabolic rate necessary for normal physiologic function&lt;/strong&gt;? How many of us have young women in their 30s and beyond that complain of brain fog, loss of muscle, increasing fat deposition, and sexual libido loss and yet their lab levels reflect normality? We must realize that what we have considered and been told is normal is truly not normal and that the range of normal testosterone needs to be adjusted to reflect the true normal production of testosterone for women which is more accurately reflected as above 70 ng/dL. This better reflects the true production of a normal young woman of 300mg daily.&lt;/em&gt;Perhaps it should be noted that researchers in these recent studies have admitted that some of the funding for this study was provided by drug companies. Hmmm toss that in the trick or treat bag.Dont let these misleading Testosterone Terrorizers or the Big Pharma Boogeyman scare you! View the hormonal imbalance symptoms checklist at &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.sottopelletherapy.com/&quot;&gt;http://www.sottopelletherapy.com/&lt;/a&gt; and take a simple hormone assessment at &lt;a href=&quot;/?page_id=333&quot;&gt;http://www.sottopelletherapy.com/self-assessment&lt;/a&gt;. Then let your own body wisdom and common sense decide if hormones are the Wicked Witch or Glenda the Good Witch leading you back home to your hormone health this Halloween!SOURCES&lt;a href=&quot;http://articles.latimes.com/2013/jul/18/science/la-sci-sn-estrogen-alone-hormone-therapy-deaths-20130718&quot;&gt;http://articles.latimes.com/2013/jul/18/science/la-sci-sn-estrogen-alone-hormone-therapy-deaths-20130718&lt;/a&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.dailyrx.com/testosterone-deficiency-difficult-diagnosis-women-and-therapy-may-be-risky-says-endocrine-society?autoplay=1002223046&quot;&gt;http://www.dailyrx.com/testosterone-deficiency-difficult-diagnosis-women-and-therapy-may-be-risky-says-endocrine-society?autoplay=1002223046&lt;/a&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Author: &lt;/strong&gt;Gino Tutera, M.D., F.A.C.O.G., is a board-certified OB/GYN who has practiced medicine combining good science and common sense for 40 years. Recognized internationally as a respected authority in the field of bio-identical hormone replacement therapy, Dr. Tutera pioneered SottoPelle in 2002. His subcutaneous method has liberated thousands of people from their debilitating symptoms and restored them back to health. For the past two decades, he has conducted seminars on his safe and scientifically proven approach while training hundreds of physicians throughout the world. He has authored three books on the subject: &lt;em&gt;You Dont Have to Live with It!, Life Regained: The Real Solution to Managing Menopause &lt;/em&gt;and &lt;em&gt;Andropause, You Dont Have to Live with It! The Science of SottoPelle.&lt;/em&gt; Dr. Tutera continues to present his groundbreaking research to medical symposiums in the U.S. and abroad, attracting global media attention as an innovative leader on the vital role of subcutaneous bio-identical hormones in human health, anti-aging and disease prevention.

title: Dr Maria Manzanares, M.D.
content: Dr. Maria Manzanares, M.D., a former Assistant Professor of Radiology in the Breast Imaging department and IRB (Institutional Review Board) member at the University of Miami Sylvester Cancer Center, has traveled and studied extensively to offer a range of modalities for wellbeing and to treat all kinds of physical and emotional ailments. Her ultimate goal is to boost the extraordinary capacities inherent to all human beings, providing healing of the mind, body and spirit.She became a Naam Yoga Therapies instructor in the U.S. before she moved to France where she studied the psychological origins of disease and advanced therapy for pain relief with Scenar technology. As a skeptical scientist she began exploring the benefits of energy healing, becoming a Reiki master, followed by Saint Germains Violet Flame in France, topping it all with Harmonyum Biometaphysical Medicine in the USA.Dr. Maria recently came back from California where she completed 2 years studying next to the founder of Naam Yoga the benefits of movement, breath and sound vibration. She is currently doing an Integrative Medicine fellowship at the University of Arizona Center, the most prestigious integrative medical education center in the world, and is a certified Sottopelle practitioner.She has been conducting scientific research and workshops in LA, Miami, Mexico and Colombia. She speaks English, Spanish, is currently improving her French, and has been interviewed on CNN, Telemundo and La Prensa.The type of medicine offered at Florida Complete Wellness, Inc., presents a new choice for approaching the physical, energetic an emotional nature of the human being, preventing and treating disease at the root and empowering people to find the path to self-healing. She would love to assist you on your healing journey!&lt;table width=&quot;100%&quot;&gt;&lt;tbody&gt;&lt;tr&gt;&lt;td&gt;Main:5810 Biscayne Blvd.Miami FL 33137T: 954-765-6505Satellite: 6601 SW 80th St, #200A , South Miami, FL 33143T:&lt;span style=&quot;color: #666666;&quot;&gt;424-262-2672&lt;/span&gt;E: &lt;a href=&quot;mailto:admin@floridacompletewellness.com&quot;&gt;admin@floridacompletewellness.com&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&lt;/tbody&gt;&lt;/table&gt;

title: Stress, Menopause, and Hormones – Finding the Healthy Balance
content: &lt;strong&gt;Stress, Menopause, and Hormones Finding the Healthy Balance&lt;/strong&gt;Youre so exhausted you cant keep your eyes open but yet you find yourself staying awake all night and cant get to sleep. Your mood swings up one day and drops the next. You feel like a furnace one minute and then freezing cold.Sound familiar?Getting through that stressful phase in our forties and fifties is hard enough. Men and women often face sudden changes in their work and family lives. Then along comes The Change for women, adding another layer to the multiple stressors.While stress shows up in our daily lives in many forms, some women entering menopause find themselves caught in a vicious cycle of stress and hormonal imbalance. One study in the &lt;em&gt;Journal of The North American Menopause Society*&lt;/em&gt; cites a correlation between menopause and anxiety. Stress can impact your health and overall quality of life as fluctuating levels of hormones play havoc with your mind and body. Progesterone, estrogen and testosterone imbalances can cause disrupted sleep, hot flashes, sexual dysfunction, weight gain, brain fog and fatigue.Dragging through the day with insufficient sleep and reaching for the caffeine will only send stress levels sky high. What can you do to get off the hormonal roller coaster ? Dont give up! Youre not going crazy even though it often feels that way. In addition to having a doctor check your hormone levels, here are some suggestions to help you manage the stresses of menopause:&amp;nbsp;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.sottopelletherapy.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/11/relax3.jpg&quot;&gt;&lt;/a&gt; Take Time to Relax&lt;ul&gt;&lt;li&gt;Set aside some quiet time each day for stillness and relaxation.&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Reduce your intake of caffeinated beverages, especially before bedtime.&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Indulge in a massage, manicure or luxurious personal treatment.&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Soak in a hot bath with scented candles and essential oils.&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Surround yourself with good company, do something you love and dont forget to laugh!&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ul&gt;November 5 is National Stress Awareness Day -- be good to yourself and visit us on &lt;a title=&quot;SottoPelle Facebook Page&quot; href=&quot;https://www.facebook.com/hormonereplacement&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Facebook&lt;/a&gt; to share your tips for handling stress!&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;SOURCES*&lt;a href=&quot;http://journals.lww.com/menopausejournal/Abstract/2005/12030/The_role_of_anxiety_and_hormonal_changes_in.6.aspx&quot;&gt;http://journals.lww.com/menopausejournal/Abstract/2005/12030/The_role_of_anxiety_and_hormonal_changes_in.6.aspx&lt;/a&gt;

title: Guest Blog - Hot Flashes, Fatigue & Depression
content: &lt;strong&gt;Guest Blogger: &lt;/strong&gt;&lt;strong&gt;James Mirabile, MD, FACOG&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;/?p=1630&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;section class=&quot;av_textblock_section&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;avia_textblock &quot;&gt;&lt;h3 style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;a title=&quot;Mirabile M.D&quot; href=&quot;http://www.mirabilemd.com&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Mirabile M.D. Beauty, Health &amp;amp; Wellness&lt;/a&gt;4550 W 109th St, Ste 130,Overland Park Kansas&lt;/h3&gt;&lt;em&gt;&lt;/em&gt;Are you suffering from symptoms of hormonal imbalance caused by perimenopause or menopause? Are you experiencing hot flashes, sleep disturbances, mood swings, memory problems, or loss of libido, among other symptoms?&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/section&gt;Many women recognize thathot flashes may be the first obvious symptom of their bodies beginning to experience perimenopause and menopause. Though hot flashes are indeed a common complaint, they are not the only symptom that women may present to their physician. You dont have to miss a period for 12 months to have symptoms associated with these changes.Natural or bio-identical hormone replacement therapy (BHRT) can help alleviate these symptoms, restoring a natural hormonal balance within the body. This type of therapy can yield exceptional results and health benefits, significantly improving your quality of life and well-being.&lt;strong&gt;What is Perimenopause and Menopause?&lt;/strong&gt;Peri is from Greek, and means near or about Perimenopause describes the time when a womans body transitions from her fertile, child-bearing years into middle age. The body undergoes biological changes resulting from declining ovarian hormone production. Peri-menopausal symptoms sometimes begin in your late 30s and early 40s. It is the beginning phase of the change and can last up to ten years.Menopause means the end of monthly cycles a woman is considered to have reached menopause when a full year has passed since her last menstrual cycle. It is a natural, gradual process typically occuring in women around the age of 50, when a womans ovaries make less estrogen and progesterone, and her lifetime supply of eggs becomes depleted.&lt;strong&gt;Symptoms of Perimenopause and Menopause&lt;/strong&gt;Women going through Perimenopause and menopause often experience a combination of some or all of the following symptoms: irregular menstrual periods, hot flashes, night sweats and/or cold flashes, clammy skin, irritability, insomnia, mood swings, sudden tears, depression, loss of libido, vaginal dryness, heart palipitations, urinary urgency, inability to sleep through the night, depression and weight gain, especially belly fat. All leading to an overall lower quality of life.&lt;strong&gt;What are Bio-Identical Hormones? &lt;/strong&gt;Hormones are chemical messengers that transport information between cells and facilitate communication among different body organs, regulating various functions of our body. The first hormone replacement supplements were developed in the 1930s to provide relief from symptoms of menopause. These first hormone supplements were bio-identical in that they had a chemical structure and biological action identical to natural hormones produced by the human body.Bio-identical hormones are derived from plants, primarily soy and yam, and undergo transformation in the chemical laboratory to create the end products, hormones. Because bio-identical hormones are identical to human hormones, our bodies can utilize and metabolize them easily, without the unpleasant and dangerous side effects that synthetic or horse hormones can have. Bio-identical hormones are prescribed by a medical doctor and are specfiically custom-made for you by a compounding pharmacist, according to a doctors prescription.&lt;strong&gt;What are Synthetic Hormones?&lt;/strong&gt;Synthetic hormone supplements were first developed in the 1940s. Synthetic hormones are derived from plant and animal progestins, and estrogens, and are usually not chemically identical to the hormones your body uses. These mass-produced synthetic hormones do NOT match the molecular structure of the naturally occurring hormones in our bodies.Current, traditional hormone replacement therapy utilizes synthetic products to alleviate the symptoms such as hot flashes and night sweats without restoring the normal hormonal balance one needs to feel good. While reducing the menopausal symptoms, synthetic hormones may generate many unpleasant side effects including water retention, breast engorgement, and weight gain. Synthetic estrogens, especially when combined with synthetic progestins, may also increase health risks including breast cancer, heart attacks, stroke and blood clots. Beacause of these side effects, many women stop their hormone replacement therapy on their own and suffer the remainder of their life.&lt;strong&gt;Restoring Natural Hormonal Balance&lt;/strong&gt;Bio-identical hormones, with their biological action and metabolic pathways identical to human hormones, not only ease the unpleasant symptoms of perimenopause, menopause and andropause (male menopause), more importantly, they restore youthful hormonal balance as well as provide the body with the same protective health benefits the bodys own natural hormones would provide.----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------About Dr. Mirabile&lt;em&gt;Sotto Bio:&lt;/em&gt; &lt;em&gt;http://www.sottopelletherapy.com/doctors/james-mirabile-md-facog/&lt;/em&gt;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;

title: Guest Blog - Hormonal Changes Affect Men Too
content: &lt;strong&gt;Guest Blogger: &lt;/strong&gt;&lt;strong&gt;James Mirabile, MD, FACOG&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;/?p=1630&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;section class=&quot;av_textblock_section&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;avia_textblock &quot;&gt;&lt;h3 style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;a title=&quot;Mirabile M.D&quot; href=&quot;http://www.mirabilemd.com&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Mirabile M.D. Beauty, Health &amp;amp; Wellness&lt;/a&gt;4550 W 109th St, Ste 130,Overland Park Kansas&lt;/h3&gt;&lt;em&gt;&lt;/em&gt;&lt;strong&gt;What is Andropause and what can you do about it? &lt;/strong&gt;Men, there comes a time when we start hearing age-related comments like &lt;em&gt;youre just getting older, &lt;/em&gt;or &lt;em&gt;youre not as young as you used to be.&lt;/em&gt; &lt;em&gt;&lt;/em&gt;Issues of masculinity can be a sensitive topic and no man wants to hear that hes losing testosterone, the very hormone that makes him a man and helps him feel masculine. In years past, the symptoms of low testosterone were attributed to normal changes associated with aging, often called a &lt;em&gt;mid-life crisis&lt;/em&gt;. Doctors typically instructed patients to accept their plight because they werent spring chickens anymore. So things like hair loss, paunchiness, or erectile dysfunction were either not discussed or symptomatically treated with anti-depressants or male enhancement drugs.&lt;strong&gt;Andropause, the male version of Menopause&lt;/strong&gt;Every man experiences a gradual decline in hormone production as he gets older. Beginning at age 30, his body starts to manufacture less and less testosterone, losing roughly one to 3 percent per year. Then, sometime between age 40 and 55, testosterone levels drop dramatically and signal the onset of Andropause, the medical term for the male equivalent of Menopause. Throughout this process, men find themselves putting on weight, losing muscle mass, feeling sluggish, feeling depressed and becoming increasingly irritable. They remember a time when they had energy for work and family, but those days are now few and far between. They find it harder to concentrate at work and their workouts are cut short by pain or fatigue that didnt previously exist. The realization is even more troubling for those men who begin to experience lack of sexual drive and impotence. If the root problem, hormonal imbalance, is not treated properly men can experience a number of physical and mental challenges including health challenges associated with weight gain and abdominal fat.&lt;strong&gt;Bio-Identical Hormone Replacement Therapy&lt;/strong&gt;For over 20 years, Ive treated womens health, including bio-identical hormone replacement therapy. Ive seen how safely restoring the body with appropriate hormone levels can literally change lives. After much research and evaluation, Im pleased to begin offering bio-identical hormone therapy to men starting this summer.Our office has chosen SottoPelle Therapy, developed by Dr. Ginto Tutera. Dr. Tutera is a pioneer and leader in the field of bio-identical hormone replacement therapy. The SottoPelle method uses subcutaneous (beneath the skin) hormone replacement pellets. The hormone replacement therapy works in partnership with your body day and night. Hormone pellet therapy provides a steady, low dose of natural hormone that flows straight into the blood stream whenever your body needs it. Hormone pellets are easy to insert and on average last in most patients for 6 months.Since 1992, SottoPelle Therapy has helped thousands of men achieve the natural healthy balance of hormones their bodies need to maintain optimum well-being. The benefits patients have reported include:&lt;ul&gt;&lt;li&gt;Enhancement of libido plus an increased sexual drive&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;An increase in lean body mass and a decrease in body fat&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;An increase in muscle weight, size and strength&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Greater capacity for getting in shape&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Consistency in moods, reduction in anger, nervousness and irritability&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Increased energy, mental focus, clarity of thought and concentration is easier to maintain&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Improvement of memory&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Increased sense of overall well being&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ul&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;To your health,&lt;/span&gt;James Mirabile, M.D.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/section&gt;----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------About Dr. Mirabile&lt;em&gt;Sotto Bio:&lt;/em&gt; &lt;em&gt;http://www.sottopelletherapy.com/doctors/james-mirabile-md-facog/&lt;/em&gt;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;

title: Are your hormones making you fat?
content: &lt;strong&gt;Guest Blogger:&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;color: #808080;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;Betsy Stander, Mirabile M.D. APRN&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;section class=&quot;av_textblock_section&quot;&gt;&lt;div class=&quot;avia_textblock &quot;&gt;&lt;h3 style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;a title=&quot;Mirabile M.D&quot; href=&quot;http://www.mirabilemd.com&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Mirabile M.D. Beauty, Health &amp;amp; Wellness&lt;/a&gt;4550 W 109th St, Ste 130,Overland Park, Kansas&lt;/h3&gt;&lt;em&gt;&lt;/em&gt;Are you struggling to lose weight even when youre doing everything right?Are you suddenly gaining weight although your diet and exercise have remained the same? Your hormones could be to blame!Hormones are important to all body functions and play a significant role in your ability to lose weight and maintain a healthy weight. There are many hormonal imbalances that can occur in the body including, but not limited to: elevated insulin, elevated cortisol, elevated or low estrogen, low testosterone, low DHEA, and hypothyroidism. It is important to recognize possible imbalances that may be occurring in the body and correct them in order to reach your weight loss goals.&lt;b&gt;Insulin the &lt;i&gt;fat storage&lt;/i&gt; hormone&lt;/b&gt;Insulin has an important job. It processes the sugar in the blood stream and carries it to your cells its then used for energy or stored for later use in the form of fat. Elevated levels of insulin can be caused by excess consumption of carbohydrates. A diet high in carbohydrates, such as processed foods and sugary beverages, in combination with a low protein and low fiber intake, can lead to the storage of fat, weight gain and high insulin levels. Poor diet along with lack of exercise, alcohol consumption, stress and high blood pressure can lead to chronically high levels of insulin and the development of Type 2 diabetes.&lt;b&gt;Cortisol the &lt;i&gt;stress &lt;/i&gt;hormone&lt;/b&gt;High levels of cortisol can be harmful to your health. Studies indicate that a high stress level can contribute to the accumulation of belly fat. Cortisol levels are higher in people who suffer from conditions such as anxiety, depression, PTSD, and excessive fatigue. Not only does elevated cortisol lead to belly fat, it also increases appetite and cravings. This is why people turn to comfort foods when feeling significant amounts of stress! Other harmful effects of high cortisol include decreased bone density, memory loss and depression. What is the best way to combat high cortisol? Get some sleep! At least 7 hours a night. It is also important to eat a high protein breakfast and find an outlet for all that stress. Activities such as yoga, meditation or even taking a long walk can help decrease stress.&lt;b&gt;Estrogen the &lt;i&gt;reproductive&lt;/i&gt; hormone&lt;/b&gt;Both men and women naturally produce estrogen. In men, an excess of belly fat can cause testosterone to be converted to estrogen. As a mans estrogen level rises, so does the fat accumulation. In addition, high levels of estrogen in men can contribute to prostate cancer and heart disease. In women, both excess estrogen and low estrogen contribute to weight gain and difficulty maintaining a healthy weight. Estrogen levels fluctuate as a woman goes through phases of her reproductive life. What can be done if you suspect an estrogen imbalance? Get your hormones tested. Testing can identify if an estrogen imbalance exists and what methods of treatment would be best. Also it is important to eat a healthy diet including green tea, flax seed and chia seeds. All of these products can assist the body in processing extra estrogen in the body.&lt;b&gt;Testosterone the &lt;i&gt;sex &lt;/i&gt;hormone&lt;/b&gt;Increased stress (high cortisol levels), abdominal fat and aging all contribute to low testosterone levels. Low levels of testosterone can lead to conditions such as depression, obesity, heart disease, loss of muscle tone, decreased stamina and decreased libido. Simple hormone testing can identify a low level of testosterone. When levels are corrected, it has been shown to decrease body fat and improve stamina, muscle mass and libido. A healthy diet in lean protein, as well as weight-bearing exercise can help naturally increase testosterone levels.&lt;b&gt;DHEA the &lt;i&gt;mother of all&lt;/i&gt; hormones&lt;/b&gt;There is much talk these days about DHEA, but what exactly is it? DHEA is a precursor hormone secreted by the adrenal glands that can be converted into testosterone or estrogen in the body. DHEA levels typically hit their peak in our 20s and then naturally decline as we age. DHEA is responsible for many important functions including the bodys ability to burn fat and keep it off. Low DHEA levels can be detected in hormone testing. Correcting an imbalance can improve libido, energy and weight loss.&lt;b&gt;Your thyroid gland&lt;/b&gt;The thyroid gland is responsible for producing hormones that regulate the bodys metabolic rate, heart and digestive function, muscle control, brain development and bone maintenance. The thyroid gland can become overactive (hyperthoyrodism) or underactive (hypothyroidism). Thyroid conditions can be quite dangerous and cause many unpleasant symptoms. For patients suffering from hypothyroidism, weight gain is a common side effect. Thyroid conditions can be safely treated with medication.&lt;b&gt;Get your levels checked&lt;/b&gt;Hormones play a significant role in your health, including weight loss and weight management. A simple blood test is the first step in understanding your hormonal health. At Mirabile M.D. Beauty, Health &amp;amp; Wellness, we are experts in the field of bio-identical hormone replacement therapy. We offer safe, natural and effective methods for both men and women. In addition, we offer Medi-Weightloss, a supervised weight loss program that works and has helped Kansas City area patients lose over 25,000 pounds! We understand how hormones impact your health and that weight gain and hormonal imbalance are often interrelated. Call to schedule your appointment: .&lt;/div&gt;&lt;/section&gt;----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------About Dr. Mirabile&lt;em&gt;Sotto Bio:&lt;/em&gt; &lt;em&gt;http://www.sottopelletherapy.com/doctors/james-mirabile-md-facog/&lt;/em&gt;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;

title: Romancing the Bone: Osteoporosis and Hormones
content: Good bones rely on healthy habits, but new studies suggest that some of our long-held beliefs on the causes and treatments for osteoporosis might just be well, a bag of bones.As we age and our hormone levels shift dramatically, maintaining normal bone density becomes critical to good health. Fluctuating levels of estrogen and testosterone decrease bone strength and increase the chance of fractures. Women who undergo premature surgical menopause also remain at greater risk of developing osteoporosis, making it critical to check their hormone levels.&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.sottopelletherapy.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/11/osteoporosis.gif&quot;&gt;&lt;/a&gt;While many menopausal women are prescribed drugs for osteoporosis, common side effects can include, surprisingly, bone loss and fractures plus blood clots, heart attacks and strokes.Before you reach for the milk container, consider a report published in Forbes* last week claiming that cows dairy causes more fractures than prevent them. While some experts will certainly find a bone to pick with that one, what can you do to maintain healthy bones without any side effects?&lt;ul&gt;&lt;li&gt;Keep moving: walking and weight-resistance training offer ideal bone-fortifying exercises&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Go for the green: one cup of kale contains more calcium than any dairy product&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Avoid stimulants: coffee and alcohol consumption which can leach healthy bones&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Increase your intake of Vitamin D&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Check your hormone levels and balance them with bio-identical pellet therapy&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ul&gt;Numerous studies suggest the effectiveness of bio-identical hormone pellet therapy in preventing bone loss and deterioration. A 1992 report* in the &lt;em&gt;British Journal of Obstetrics and Gynecology&lt;/em&gt; shows significant improvement in the bone mineral density of patients administered subcutaneous testosterone and estradiol pellets. Testosterone augments bone density, strength and ability to repair itself.According to a new report from the International Osteoporosis Foundation,* women arent the only ones who need to bone up on calcium. The foundation cites osteoporosis as the cause for broken bones in one out of every five men over 50 who are twice as likely as women to die from these fractures. It also finds that osteoporosis causes 27 percent more men to suffer a bone fracture than develop prostate cancer.Make no bones about it bio-identical hormone pellets offer a safe, natural approach that help prevent osteoporosis. Unlike other pellet therapies, SottoPelles web-based BioCalc system provides patients with a precise dose of the highest quality bio-identical hormone pellets designed to meet their individual needs. Guys and gals can learn more about building their bones at &lt;a href=&quot;/?page_id=260&quot;&gt;http://www.sottopelletherapy.com/what-is-hormone-replacement-therapy/&lt;/a&gt;.SOURCES:&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.forbes.com/sites/alicegwalton/2014/11/03/study-suggests-milk-may-actually-increase-the-risk-of-bone-fracture/&quot;&gt;http://www.forbes.com/sites/alicegwalton/2014/11/03/study-suggests-milk-may-actually-increase-the-risk-of-bone-fracture/&lt;/a&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.gulfshorelife.com/Along-the-Gulfshore/November-2014/International-Osteoporosis-Foundation-osteoporosis-in-men-The-Feel-Good-Report/&quot;&gt;http://www.gulfshorelife.com/Along-the-Gulfshore/November-2014/International-Osteoporosis-Foundation-osteoporosis-in-men-The-Feel-Good-Report/&lt;/a&gt;&lt;em&gt;British Journal of Obstetrics and Gynecology&lt;/em&gt;, Increase in bone mass after one year of percutaneous estradiol and testosterone implants in postmenopausal women, Savvas et al, Kings College Hospital, Vol. 99, pp 757-760, 1992&lt;em&gt;Obstetrics and Gynecology&lt;/em&gt;, Estradiol Implants, Notelovitz et al, The American College of Obstetrics and Gynecology, 1987

title: Letting it Grow Wild and Free – It is No-Shave November
content: Everywhere you look, men are sporting beards. Its colder outside, but what is the sudden interest in facial hair? Beards are back, and just in time for No-Shave November. Nobody likes going to the doctor and men are notorious for neglecting their health, especially when terms like prostrate exam are mentioned in hushed whispers. As October ends and the national attention to breast cancer awareness month subsides, its time to bring attention to men too.The concept is built around an initiative that partners with the American Cancer Society to grow awareness for cancer patients who lose hair by asking others to let it grow wild and free. The goals are awareness and the hope that the money saved by growing it out will be donated to cancer prevention. To find out more about No-Shave November visit: &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.no-shave.org/#!what/cjg9&quot;&gt;http://www.no-shave.org/#!what/cjg9&lt;/a&gt;Everyone is ready to get into a hairy situation to support and raise awareness for mens health.Matt, Al, Willie and Carson have found themselves in some hairy situations over the years, but starting November 1, theyll define that word in a whole new way.The anchors along with a handful of TODAY staffers are kicking off &quot;No-Shave November.&quot; The group will be throwing away their razors and going &lt;em&gt;au naturel&lt;/em&gt; for the entire month in an effort to raise awareness for mens health, specifically prostate and testicular cancer.They wont be doing it alone. The dudes of NBC News will join thousands of bearded and mustachioed men across the globe. A number of programs, &lt;a href=&quot;http://us.movember.com/mens-health/resources/&quot;&gt;including Movember&lt;/a&gt;, look to bring attention to issues of mens health during the month of November.At SottoPelle we support No-Shave November and want to assist in raising awareness to Mens Health.As a leading expert in hormonal balance and age management, Dr. Tutera shares these tips for how men can enjoy longer and healthier lives:&lt;ul&gt;&lt;li&gt;Dont wait until theres a problem. Check your blood pressure, heart and cholesterol now to avoid trouble down the road.&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Got a beer belly? Get off the couch and get it checked. Pot bellies can signal underlying health issues like metabolic syndrome, diabetes and liver disorders. A high Body Mass Index (BMI) puts you at risk for many chronic diseases.&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Real men eat real food. Chips and beer go hand in hand with football, but cutting down on sugar, salt and processed foods promotes good health. Load up on lean protein instead.&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Lost your vim and vigor? Men can put their health back in the drivers seat with a simple road test to detect low testosterone levels that can be effectively treated with natural bio-identical hormone pellets to help restore energy and vitality.&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ul&gt;Can women participate in No-Shave November? Of course, Mo Sistas Movember and the American Cancer Society encourages BOTH men and women to join the cause and put down the razor, join the movement, and support the men in your life to grow some hair and awareness about mens health. Fighting cancer is a team effort, and we ask that you help.Please post a picture of your great beard or how youre participating in No-Shave November and show your support.&lt;em&gt;Sources: &lt;/em&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;em&gt;http://www.today.com/allday/matt-lauer-al-roker-willie-geist-carson-daly-wont-shave-8C1149338&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://us.movember.com/about/vision-goals&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;em&gt;http://us.movember.com/about/vision-goals&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp; http://www.today.com/allday/matt-lauer-al-roker-willie-geist-carson-daly-wont-shave-8C11493380

title: Tips for a Terrific Thanksgiving
content: People are getting ready to cook, spend time with lived ones and shop sales. It sounds like a recipe for gratitude or disaster.The holiday is a time that makes people very stressed. Some of the biggest causes of holiday stress are noted in a Consumer Reports Survey:&quot;The holidays are supposed to be a time of comfort and joy, but 90% of Americans report stressing over at least one aspect of the merry season. &quot;For all the chatter about nostalgia, family fun, and gift giving this time of year, many people dont like too much of a good thing,&quot; said Tod Marks, senior editor at Consumer Reports.Here are the top 11 things that Americans dread about Christmas, according to a survey by the Consumer Reports National Research Center:68%: Crowds and long lines37%: Gaining weight37%: Getting into debt28%: Gift shopping25%: Traveling24%: Seeing certain relatives23%: Seasonal music19%: Disappointing gifts16%: Having to attend holiday parties or events15%: Having to be nice12%: Holiday tipping &quot;So how do we minimize our stress and actually enjoy the holiday season more?Take a breath and relax. If crowds and lines are an issue, then try shopping online. Also, factor in your time, effort, and stress before deciding if that holiday sale really is a great bargain? If you have to shop, try avoiding peak times of shopping. Shop with someone to offset the stress.Enjoy holiday food, but moderation in all things matter. If you know your going to be eating a lot or unhealthy things, try exercising more to offset the holiday barrage of calories.Many people feel an overwhelming pressure to buy gifts they cannot afford. Instead of using charge cards, use your debit cards to control spending cash on hand. Gifts are thoughtful gestures, if you have that family member who puts no thought into gift giving, lower your expectations on what you will get and focus on giving from the heart.During the holiday season, most of us are our own worst enemy. We dont take care of ourselves. Its hard not to be stressed if your eating poorly, not sleeping well, and dealing with the craziness that comes with the holiday season.&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.sottopelletherapy.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/11/animated-turkey-with-football.gif&quot;&gt;&lt;/a&gt;Get lots of sleep, sunlight, and try to find humor in unpleasant situations.Plan for the worst and hope for the best. Holiday stress management can often seem like an exercise in survival skills.WebMD also provides these tips to reduce stress during the holidays:1. Put Stress in its Place: Its Not About the HolidaysPeople who get stressed out easily are most likely to feel intense stress during the holidays. Its really all about you, and not about the holidays. But theres good news. You can learn to put stress in its place, and take the pressure off throughout the year.&quot;Stress and distress are often related to worrying about the future or fretting about the past,&quot; says David Levingston, LMFT, a licensed marriage and family therapist in Brattleboro, Vt. To find peace and joy in any season, he advises focusing on the present moment.2. Create the Holiday You Want&quot;When the holidays come around, there may be pressures pulling you in all directions off your center,&quot; Levingston says. He suggests you make clear decisions about how you want to spend your time and resources. Do it early, before the decorations go up around town. Consider what is most important to you. What memories will you look back on when the season winds down?3. Have Compassion for Yourself and OthersEven if you shop less and focus on family time, stressed-out friends, in-laws, and co-workers may still come calling. How can you be a good friend and keep your calm?Try not to take things personally. Levingston says thats one of the most important skills you can learn to reduce stress. During the holidays in particular, he says, most people are trying to get their needs met. Maybe its their need for love or simply for validation. &quot;Even if someone is being a jerk or insensitive, it is their way of trying to get their needs met,&quot; Levingston says.So try not to think about how people &quot;should be.&quot; Accept them as they are, and release the tension from your body. &quot;I think when we can see where people are coming from, there can be less frustration and more compassion,&quot; Levingston says.SottoPelle wishes you a happy, healthy, and stress free Thansgiving!Sources:&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.prevention.com/mind-body/emotional-health/solutions-holiday-stress&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;http://www.prevention.com/mind-body/emotional-health/solutions-holiday-stress&lt;/a&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.webmd.com/parenting/family-health-12/reduce-holiday-stress?page=3&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;http://www.webmd.com/parenting/family-health-12/reduce-holiday-stress?page=3&lt;/a&gt;

title: Giving Tuesday
content: &lt;strong&gt;Turn Giving Tuesday into an Everyday Event!&lt;/strong&gt;If laughter is the best medicine, then giving must be a close runner up! Performing a random act of kindness will do more good for your health and spirits than any gift on your holiday shopping list.The annual Day of Giving falls on the first Tuesday in December as a timely reminder for kindness and generosity after the shopping frenzy of Black Friday and Cyber Mondays whopping sales.Retailers like Walmart are donating $1.5 million to help food pantries as part of Giving Tuesday, after reporting record sale numbers last weekend. Celebs are also contributing to the efforts of kindness on Giving Tuesday. Actor Ed Norton is building momentum via a mobile app called Crowdrise that allows users to monitor donations via a virtual tower with photos of the donors at &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.crowdrise.com/givingtower&quot;&gt;https://www.crowdrise.com/givingtower&lt;/a&gt;.Giving Tuesday provides a great opportunity for all of us to get creative in our giving too. Think of all the ways you can do good not just today or this week but throughout the remainder of the year. Lets expand the Day of Giving by spreading the joy of generosity all the time.As businesses around the world from Microsoft , Walmart and eBay announce big benefits for Giving Tuesday, Sottopelle is doing its part too. Were participating with our annual Toys for Tots drive, and planning a full calender of events that will benefit many people and charitable organizations.We believe that creating a better and healthier world is everyones business. Anyone can make a difference in someones life, they just have to start today with one random act of kindness. Here are some simple ways you can give and share the spirit of kindness:&lt;ul&gt;&lt;li&gt;Donate a safe toy to Toys for Tots&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Lend a hand to a family in need from babysitting to running errands&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Volunteer at your favorite charity or community center&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Deliver a meal to the elderly or a homeless person&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Offer a kind word or a smile to a stranger&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Let someone else have that last parking space near the doorCheck out more creative ideas at &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.givingtuesday.org/ideas/&quot;&gt;http://www.givingtuesday.org/ideas/&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ul&gt;Are you already giving back to the world today? Learn more about Giving Tuesday and things you can do to help make the world a happier place at &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.givingtuesday.org/&quot;&gt;http://www.givingtuesday.org/&lt;/a&gt;. Then drop us a line and let us know how ? Share your stories and ideas on our Facebook page at &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.facebook.com/hormonereplacement&quot;&gt;https://www.facebook.com/hormonereplacement&lt;/a&gt; and INSPIRE others to share some kindness every giving act matters!SOURCES&lt;a href=&quot;http://wishtv.com/2014/12/02/giving-tuesday-movement-grows/&quot;&gt;http://wishtv.com/2014/12/02/giving-tuesday-movement-grows/&lt;/a&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.cnbc.com/id/102232442&quot;&gt;http://www.cnbc.com/id/102232442&lt;/a&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://abcnews.go.com/Business/edward-norton-elevate-giving-tuesday-black-fridays-popularity/story?id=27284813&quot;&gt;http://abcnews.go.com/Business/edward-norton-elevate-giving-tuesday-black-fridays-popularity/story?id=27284813&lt;/a&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;https://time.com/3613467/walmart-breaks-sales-record-cyber-monday/&quot;&gt;https://time.com/3613467/walmart-breaks-sales-record-cyber-monday/&lt;/a&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Giving_Tuesday&quot;&gt;http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Giving_Tuesday&lt;/a&gt;

title: Celebrate without Gaining Weight! 5 Tips to Burn Holiday Calories
content: Did you stuff yourself silly on Thanksgiving and enjoy an extra piece of pie? Its OK to indulge a little on the holidays. But now youre wearing those second helpings on your hips with a belly thats starting to look a lot like Santa, and there are still plenty of parties ahead.According to the Calorie Control Council, Americans consume up to 4,500 calories in one sitting with a typical Thanksgiving meal. The councils exercise converter shows that it would take 15 hours of skiing to burn off those calories that are the equivalent of seven Big Macs!Finding the balance between holiday merrymaking and healthy eating is challenging for most people at this time of year. Slipping in a few good habits in between those yummy egg-nogs will help you avoid any major holiday weight gain without feeling totally deprived.One study in the journal &lt;em&gt;Medicine and Science in Sports and Exercise&lt;/em&gt; shows that 45 minutes of early morning exercise helps reduce food cravings and keeps your metabolism fired up all day.Obesity experts also claim that starving yourself all day before the holiday bash wont reduce the calories. Arriving hungry usually results in sugar binges, which can lower your immune system. Eating balanced meals in between the festivities will help prevent common seasonal illnesses like colds and flu while helping you stay trim.Here are some suggestions that can help so you can have your holiday cake and eat it too without packing on the pounds:&lt;ul&gt;&lt;li&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Eat before the feast&lt;/strong&gt;: arrive half full so you dont overload on the junk&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Use smaller plates&lt;/strong&gt;: studies prove this reduces food intake&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Follow the 3-bite rule&lt;/strong&gt;: enjoy a taste or two of that dessert but dont eat the whole thing&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Day on, day off&lt;/strong&gt;: if you overloaded yesterday, take a day off and eat healthy food tomorrow&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Balance your hormones&lt;/strong&gt;: testosterone supports carbohydrate metabolism and builds muscle&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ul&gt;The Calorie Control Council offers many tips and resources for preventing holiday weight gain, plus makeover recipes for common holiday foods at &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.caloriecontrol.org/&quot;&gt;http://www.caloriecontrol.org/&lt;/a&gt;. For more information on hormonal balance and weight issues, visit &lt;a href=&quot;/?cat_ID=87&quot;&gt;http://www.sottopelletherapy.com/category/weight-loss/&lt;/a&gt;.How do you celebrate the holidays and avoid extra weight? Post your tips on our Facebook page at &lt;a href=&quot;https://www.facebook.com/hormonereplacement&quot;&gt;https://www.facebook.com/hormonereplacement&lt;/a&gt;. Seasons Eatings!&lt;strong&gt;SOURCES&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19092692&quot;&gt;http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/19092692&lt;/a&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.caloriecontrol.org/articles-and-video/feature-articles/stuff-the-bird-not-yourself&quot;&gt;http://www.caloriecontrol.org/articles-and-video/feature-articles/stuff-the-bird-not-yourself&lt;/a&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2012/09/120912161554.htm&quot;&gt;http://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2012/09/120912161554.htm&lt;/a&gt; - Brigham Young University. &quot;Exercise may affect food motivation.&quot; ScienceDaily 12 September 2012&amp;nbsp;

title: The Benefits of Yoga – Hormones, Memory, Aging, Stress & Pain
content: &lt;strong&gt;A featured guest blog by &lt;a title=&quot;Payge McMahon&quot; href=&quot;http://www.turnthepayge.com&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Payge McMahon&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;The practice of meditation and yoga, a mind-body therapy, slows down the aging process and can help those suffering from traumatic brain injuries, post-traumatic stress disorder, chronic stress, back pain, anxiety and depression.By linking breath with meditation and movement, yoga connects the physical and mental self. It increases energy, strength, flexibility, agility and balance, while improving mental and cognitive functioning.&lt;strong&gt;Recent Studies&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;While yoga has been around for thousands of years, recent studies from Harvard, the University of California and the University of Maryland have measured the physiological changes of yoga and meditation through neuro-imaging and genomics technology.There is a true biological effect, says John Weber Denninger, M.D.,PH.D., Director of Research at the Benson-Henry Institute for Mind Body Medicine at Massachusetts General Hospital, one of Harvard Medical Schools teaching hospitals. The kinds of things that happen when you meditate do have effects throughout the body, not just in the brain.University of California at Los Angeles and Nobel Prize winner Elizabeth Blackburn found that 12 minutes of daily yoga meditation for eight weeks increased telomerase activity, an anti-aging enzyme, by 43 percent, suggesting an improvement in stress-induced aging.&lt;strong&gt;Benefits - Hormones, Memory &amp;amp; Aging&lt;/strong&gt;There are thousands of yoga poses or postures, also known as &lt;em&gt;asanas&lt;/em&gt;. Each one has a multitude of benefits. Aside from building strength and flexibility, different poses can also improve the functioning of the endocrine system, which helps the body adapt to hormonal fluctuations, minimize oxidative stress that reduces skins elasticity as we age, boost immunity levels, endorphins and blood circulation that can improve mental and cognitive performance.&lt;strong&gt;Getting Started:&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Ujjayi (Oceans Breath)&lt;/strong&gt;Linking breath with mediation and movement is key. The Ujjayi breathing technique invigorates the body while calming the mind. It helps concentration, holding yoga postures and moving from one pose to another.&lt;ol&gt;&lt;li&gt;Eyes can be open or closed&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Place the tongue to the roof of your mouth&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Through your nose, take a long, smooth inhale&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Through your nose, take an equally long, smooth exhale&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Repeat&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ol&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;strong&gt;Try These 2 Poses&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Shavasana (Corpse Pose)&lt;/strong&gt;The restorative pose of shavasana or savasana is ideal for relaxation and mediation.It can be done lying down on your back or stomach, with or without a pillow, arms relaxed and legs stretched out or bent with feet together. Engage the Ujjayi breathing technique.&amp;nbsp;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.sottopelletherapy.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/12/IMG_7806-Version-2.jpg&quot;&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.sottopelletherapy.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/12/IMG_7823-Version-2.jpg&quot;&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Adho Mukha Svanasana (Downward Facing Dog)&lt;/strong&gt;This active, inversion pose is ideal for releasing tension from thespine, building stamina, stretching and strengthening the back, hamstrings, calves, shoulders, arms and hands. It calms the nervous system and can help relieve stress, insomnia, fatigue, headaches and the symptoms of menopause.Start on your hands and knees, knees are hip-width apart, hands are shoulder width apart, fingers spread and along with palms firmly planted on the ground.&lt;ol&gt;&lt;li&gt;Curling toes under, lifting the hips, pressing hands into the floor, straighten the arms and legs, flatten the back and your body will come into a V shaped pose.&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Continue pressing yourself back, into your hamstrings, by distributing the weight evenly through your fingers and palms.&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Squeeze the thigh muscles and turn triceps inward.&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Let the neck be an extension of your spine. Gaze should rest underneath body.&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Breathe (Ujjayi)&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ol&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.sottopelletherapy.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/12/IMG_7815-Version-2.jpg&quot;&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;strong&gt;Payge McMahon&lt;/strong&gt; is a yoga instructor and journalist. She specializes in training athletes and those recovering from injuries.She combines the best of Vinyasa, Budokon (martial arts influenced) and Iyengar yoga to maximize athletes performance and reduce recovery time.Payge received her yoga teaching certification in 2008, through YogaWorks in KohPhangan, Thailand. She has studied in India and Nepal, trained with Shiva Rea, DDP(Diamond Dallas Page) and &lt;em&gt;Yoga for Athletes &lt;/em&gt;author, Sage Rountree. Payge has a B.A. from Pennsylvania State University and an MBA from California Lutheran University.For more information: &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.turnthepayge.com&quot;&gt;http://www.turnthepayge.com&lt;/a&gt;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;

title: Feeling SCROOGED this Holiday?
content: The old song says &lt;em&gt;you better not cry, you better not shout&quot;&lt;/em&gt; but, the holiday season can make the best of us want to scream. Dont worry youre not alone, and to unite all those feeling that extra pressure during the holiday season, Humbug Day is here for you!Scream, Shout, and Vent - let go of all that seasonal stress, at least for today. As in the words of our favorite Frozen Princess:&lt;p style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;Let it go, let it goCant hold it back anymoreLet it go, let it goTurn away and slam the doorI dont care what theyre going to sayLet the storm rage onThe cold never bothered me anyway&lt;/p&gt;The holiday season is not always as fun as it should be (especially now that you wont be able to stop humming that Frozen song). It can be a very isolating time for many people, especially when people lose sight of what really matters in search of that perfect gift for Aunt Sue. Remember that shopping does not bring us the meaning of life, nor does one present make or break a day.National Humbug Day provides an outlet for venting your frustrations with the element of humor to allow a much needed &quot;blow off some steam&quot; before the festive season hits us all like an avalanche. It is no coincidence that the Grinch is green is it? Is he green from all the holiday cake or Christmas carols? Is it the jealousy of not having what he thinks others have? The moral of a Christmas Carol and Scrooge was that of self-redemption, so redeem yourself by letting out your stress and allow yourself to enjoy what has probably been there all along.Any ground rules for Bah Humbug Day? Take a break from the holiday madness and become a Scrooge for one day. Think of yourself and take a much needed mental vacation day. Vent and shout &quot;Bah Humbug: a few times today - but try not to exceed a dozen as then you may just be annoying the other Grinches.&lt;strong&gt;Here are some ways to celebrate and bring out the Humbug hiding within:&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;ol&gt;&lt;li&gt;Avoid ALL and ANY Christmas music. If a holiday song comes on the radio, scream &quot;bah humbug&quot; and turn to another station quickly.&quot; If youre in the mall or in a department store, wear ear muffs (preferable green furry ones). When your bestie turns on her Michael Bubl Christmas CD, roll your eyes, and leave the room in disgust.&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Quote Grinch or Scrooge the entire day.&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ol&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Some sample quotes to mutter:&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;ul&gt;&lt;li&gt;&lt;em&gt;Bah, Humbug Try it with an English Accent - it will get attention to your venting.&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;&lt;em&gt;&lt;/em&gt;&lt;em&gt;&quot;I want to wail in self-pity, and stare into the abyss&quot;&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;&lt;em&gt;&lt;/em&gt;&lt;em&gt;&quot;hate, hate, hate, double hate....loathe entirely&quot;&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ul&gt;If you still are not feeling the Bah Humbug then immediately:&lt;ol&gt;&lt;li&gt;Lock the door&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Cuddle up on the couch,&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Grab big tub of ice cream by yourself&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Watch How the Grinch Stole Christmas.&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ol&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;em&gt;Bah Humbug to All !!!&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;

title: Happy Holly Daze For Menopausal Women
content: Guest Blog by &lt;a title=&quot;Menopause Goddess Blog&quot; href=&quot;http://www.menopausegoddessblog.com/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;border-collapse: separate; color: #000000; font-family: Lucida Casual; font-size: medium; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: normal; letter-spacing: normal; line-height: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: auto; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;border-collapse: separate; color: #000000; font-family: Lucida Casual; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: normal; letter-spacing: normal; line-height: normal; orphans: 2; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;border-collapse: separate; color: #000000; font-family: Lucida Casual; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: normal; letter-spacing: normal; line-height: normal; orphans: 2; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;border-collapse: separate; color: #000000; font-family: Lucida Casual; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: normal; letter-spacing: normal; line-height: normal; orphans: 2; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;font-size: 18px;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;font-family: Bradley Hand ITC TT;&quot;&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;color: #844618;&quot;&gt;Lynette Sheppard&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/a&gt;I love, love, love the holidays, I also dread, dread, dread the busyness of the season. (Which seems to happen earlier each year or is this just my imagination?) And with the advent of menopause - well, lets just say that I dont handle the stress nearly as well as before the Big M.A few years ago, I began to wonder why I get myself all worked up and frantic carrying out the mandatory rituals every November-December. Its not always easy to score a live tree here on my rural island, so I often opt out of the pine needle, broken ornaments (cause by cattus domesticus who cant stop playing with the shiny things), sugary dough all over the kitchen, unwritten Christmas card mess.And it is...heavenly.This year, Ive been way more gentle with myself. Thanksgiving was glorious at our neighbors house - potlucked of course. The day was lazy and filled with gratitude for us.We had a second Thanksgivingat home, just so we could have leftovers for sandwiches. No one was invited save us, so it didnt matter when the turkey got done or how many side dishes or if we even had dessert.Wow, two holiday feasts already and no stress so far. Im thinking that I may be on to something. Because the rituals have been cominapart at the seams, in the very best possible way, it was with absolute serenity that we cruised downtown to see the Christmas parade of lights and hang out with the entire islands population to celebrate, Hawaiian style.I am having a tree trimming party. Which involves putting miniature ornaments on a Lilliputian fake tree (about 4 inches tall). Yes, I mean inches, not feet. I can hold it in the palm of my hand.Of course, there will be eggnog and wine. We can sing Christmas carols. (Or not, maybe itd better to listen to Willie K. or Na Leo Pilimehana sing.) And well even have the right smells, thanks to dear friend and Menopause Goddess Teri Waross Kalele Bookstore and Divine Expressions - provider of the Douglas Fir incenseYou are all invited. Happy stress free holiday and Mele Kalikimaka.&amp;nbsp;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;em&gt;Lynette Sheppards Menopause Goddess Blog was named a &quot;A Top Menopause Blog&quot; of 2014 by Healthline.&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;div id=&quot;stcpDiv&quot; style=&quot;position: absolute; top: -1999px; left: -1988px;&quot;&gt;Lynette Sheppard&lt;/div&gt;In addition to being the official Scribe for the Goddesses, the author has these credentials.&lt;ul&gt;&lt;li&gt;A former Nurse-Manager, head of Intensive Care and Coronary Care units in Santa Rosa, California for 10+ years, with a focus on both allopathic and alternative medicine.A published author of numerous articles on healing and health.&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;A featured speaker at national health symposia, such as American Association of Critical Care Nursing, National Hyperbaric Medicine Symposium, International Association of Human Caring in Melbourne, Australia.&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;A midlife, menopausal woman who continues to go through changes and is lucky enough to have the Goddesses to help her through them.&lt;em&gt;- See more at: http://www.menopausegoddessblog.com/lynette-goddesses/&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ul&gt;&lt;div id=&quot;stcpDiv&quot; style=&quot;position: absolute; top: -1999px; left: -1988px;&quot;&gt;In addition to being the official Scribe for the Goddesses, the author has these credentials. She is:A former Nurse-Manager, head of Intensive Care and Coronary Care units in Santa Rosa, California for 10+ years, with a focus on both allopathic and alternative medicine.A published author of numerous articles on healing and health.A featured speaker at national health symposia, such as American Association of Critical Care Nursing, National Hyperbaric Medicine Symposium, International Association of Human Caring in Melbourne, Australia.An expert on the Enneagram of personality; author of &lt;em&gt;The Everyday Enneagram, A Personality Map For Enhancing Your Work, Love, and LifeEveryday&lt;/em&gt;, she consults with myriad businesses and organizations. &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.9points.com/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;www.9points.com&lt;/a&gt;A hula dancer learning Hawai`ian language in her adopted home of Moloka`i.A photographer and artist.A midlife, menopausal woman who continues to go through changes and is lucky enough to have the Goddesses to help her through them.- See more at: http://www.menopausegoddessblog.com/lynette-goddesses/#sthash.tnv60kgl.dpuf&lt;/div&gt;&amp;nbsp;
