title: The Difference between Menopause and Andropause
content: While women are well aware of the fact that they will someday enter into menopause, many men are unaware of the term andropause. This term refers to a time when their reproductive hormones drop tremendously. It usually occurs between the ages 40 and 60 and is commonly listed under a variety of medical terms.When female menopause occurs, the ovaries cease to function or only intermittently. This means that ovulation and menstruation both end and that the female will eventually begin losing estrogen and testosterone hormones as well. She will be unable to have children at the completion of menopause.When a man enters andropause, he will begin to see either a gradual or significant drop in his testosterone levels. However, while a woman will no longer be able to have children, this is untrue for a man after andropause. His sperm production will continue and he will be able to father children well into his golden years.Menopause is a natural reaction to a womans body aging. However, there are some variables that can cause early onset in life. For example, women who excessively drink alcohol, have certain hormonal deficiencies, are obese or have a poor diet are all at risk from menopause occurring sooner rather than later. For women who have their ovaries or uterus removed, this will also speed up the process of menopause as well.One of the most common similarities that men and women will experience between menopause and andropause is that they are quickly returned to how they were before they entered into puberty. The symptoms that they experience through this process are often similar as well.Some of the most common symptoms that have been reported with both men and women are moodiness, depression, brain fog, hot flashes, night sweats, hair loss, low sex drive, weight gain, vaginal dryness in women and erectile dysfunction in men, among many other complaints. Both men and women experience a sense of lack of sexuality and ultimately loss of control of their own bodies.Mid-life crisis as well as other noted psychological and emotional variations will also be noticed among both sexes as well. Just as in puberty when your hormones were on a rollercoaster, you may feel like you have returned to that crazy ride during menopause and andropause.Both medical phases of life have certain treatments that are available, effective, and that are medically recognized to improve quality of life. One of the most common treatment paths for both conditions is bio identical hormone replacement therapy (BHRT). For both men and women this method will help to bring the hormone levels back to the proper levels. Managing the source of the problem delivers great relief in experienced symptons.It is important that a patient is carefully monitored by a doctor while they are undergoing BHRT treatment. The doctor should be experienced, trained, and empathize with what the patient is going through. Make sure your doctor is not just treating symptons, but the hormonal imbalance that both sexes have in middle age. Educate yourself, men and women can learn a lot if they research the different things that can be expected when experiencing these conditions. If you opt for BHRT make sure you receive quality care and pellets from a verified SottoPelle physician. Not all BHRT pellet treatment is created equally. But, when it comes to aging both men and women have equal issues and can be improved with the appropriate treatment and healthy lifestyle.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;

title: The Age of the "Selfie"
content: The world is all about the selfie. As a culture we are consumed with body image, how we look to other people. Our cell phones now have cameras that have selfie mode to help us take pictures of ourselves easier. Then we can edit those images on our phones with beauty settings. The selfie is now transformed into something far different than ourselves. This obsession with how we look does not end with the awkward teenage years, it is following us until our middle age and beyond.&lt;strong&gt;&lt;em&gt;Is this a new occurrence? What is body mage? How is it defined? What happens to our body image as we reach middle age?&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.sottopelletherapy.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/blog.jpg&quot;&gt;&lt;/a&gt; No Expiration Date on BeautyBody image obsession is not a new thing. Over the centuries, women would corset themselves in search of the perfect hourglass figure. Ironically, this practice has recently seen a sudden resurgence in popularity. &lt;strong&gt;What is old becomes new again&lt;/strong&gt;. Rubenesque figures were very much in fashion for a time as a sign of affluence, but we saw this trend quickly dissipate in the 1960s with models like twiggy. Weight should not be determined by what is in style but what is healthiest for the person.There has been a louder voice for acceptance for those who do not meet the weight standard we see on TV, magazines, social media, and basically everywhere. Many people live with the ingrained feeling that their own bodies are their enemy. Betraying them at every meal.One young writer discusses how her self image is determined by external influences:&quot;The irony of body image is not based on how other people really see you, but only how you see yourself. It is not just a visual thing, but your sense and control your body as you move. How you feel in your body, not just about your body.&quot; &quot;If youd asked me when I was a little girl what I wanted to be when I grew up, I would have told you &lt;em&gt;thin.&lt;/em&gt; I lived and breathed the dreams of slenderness.The distance between my actual self and the self I wanted to be was massive, an impassable chasm that only seemed to grow with each skipped meal and each hour spent waiting for that special day the day I wouldnt be &lt;em&gt;me&lt;/em&gt; anymore.&lt;strong&gt;Because I was a girl, self-hatred was part of my cultural inheritance.&quot;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;If a person has a weak body image, then middle age will only overwhelm them. The changes in our body as men and women age are often traumatic to many individuals. Sudden weight gain, loss of hair, or growing too much hair, and the roller coaster of hormones can cause body image perceptions to falter further. Even with the most confident of people, body image takes a hard blow during middle age.If you are a person who is very body centric, then middle age will be a harder time to handle.Women who are more concerned with their physical appearance tend to have more negative attitudes about menopause, according to a new study published in the &lt;em&gt;Journal of Health Psychology&lt;/em&gt;. To reach that conclusion, researchers surveyed 270 middle-aged women on topics like body image and perspective on menopause, and also engaged in more in-depth interviews with a handful of study participants. Unfortunately, the team also found, women with poor attitudes about menopause might be more likely to suffer from mental and physical health problems during their menopausal years.Why the link? Because our appearance (not to mention our sex drive and mood) tends to change during menopause. So women whove become used to being noticed, and have enjoyed the attention this bringslink menopause with aging and come to resent this phase and feel badly about it, says the studys lead author, Helena Rubinstein, PhD, a professor in the department of psychology at the University of Cambridge.What can you do to change your body image? The first thing to know, is that changing your body image does not mean changing your body. It is a lot like an opinion. You have to educate, research, and develop it to reach a balanced and objective one.Everyone wants to look like the ideal, but as the video below shows, those ideals are often not even real. The best way to improve your body image at ANY age is to start with health and happiness. Some suggestions from WebMD for improving our body image seem pretty easy and are mostly common sense, but it works:Start on the inside. For instance, can you stop saying you &quot;hate&quot; certain parts of your body and start appreciating what your body does for you every day, from your lungs breathing, your heart beating, your brain guiding you through the days challenges, and your hands making a meal or holding someone elses hand?Being active, eating healthy food, and getting plenty of rest will also help.Eating healthy can promote healthy skin and hair along with strong bones. Exercise has been shown to boost self-esteem, self-image, and energy. Getting enough rest is key to stress management. All of these can make you feel good about your body.&lt;em&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Most of all, learn to love yourself and you will quickly see yourself as others have all along!&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/em&gt;&lt;em&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Sources:&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/em&gt;&lt;em&gt; http://www.nationaleatingdisorders.org/what-body-image&lt;/em&gt;&lt;em&gt; http://everydayfeminism.com/2013/05/lose-hate-not-weight/&lt;/em&gt;&lt;em&gt; http://www.prevention.com/mind-body/emotional-health/menopause-body-image-advice&lt;/em&gt;&lt;em&gt; http://www.webmd.com/beauty/style/love_your_body_inside_and_out&lt;/em&gt;

title: Super Bowl Game Plan
content: Its almost game day, you have spent the whole season watching and cheering your favorite team. A season filled with Sundays of chips, dips, and drinks. Super Bowl often means a day most people will overdo the snacks and alcohol. How do you have a fun tailgate or watch party, and be healthy? Be proactive, before heading out make your game plan. Before the pre-game festivities begin, WebMD offers these tips: &quot;eat a light snack before you go so that you wont get tipsy with the first drink; it should also help reduce the temptation to dive into the food. Choose drinks that are relatively simple, such as coffee, tea, juice, wine, wine spritzers, light beer, or drinks mixed with low-calorie mixers. Sweet or creamy drinks add lots of extra fat and calories. Rum and diet cola or vodka and soda with a twist are good lower-calorie drink options. &quot;(1) When it comes to Super Bowl even the CDC has advice. People tend to overdo it, so they advise to avoid: binge drinking, drinks with unknown alcohol content, or mixing alcohol with energy drinks. Take steps to make sure you and other guests avoid driving under the influence of alcohol. Plan ahead. Always designate a non drinking driver before any party or celebration begins. Dont drink and drive or let others drink and drive. Be a helpful host by reminding your guests to designate a sober driver and offer alcohol-free beverages.&quot; (2) Remember to drink water and keep hydrated. Super Bowl is usual mid flu season, so getting worn down by over doing it can make you more susceptible to getting sick. Public places, flu season, dehydration, or junk foods are all a recipe for a bad hangover or feeling badly Monday morning after the game. If you are tailgating or outside, dress warmly and comfortable. This years Super Bowl is in Arizona, so the weather at the game should be comfortable for those fortunate enough to attend. All these tips are common sense, but many get caught up in the fan fun and forget to plan ahead for these scenarios. Be safe and plan for a fun game day. (1) &lt;a title=&quot;Healthy Super Bowl Party&quot; href=&quot;http://www.m.webmd.com/diet/features/have-a-super-healthy-super-bowl-celebration?page=3&quot;&gt;http://www.m.webmd.com/diet/features/have-a-super-healthy-super-bowl-celebration?page=3&lt;/a&gt; (2)&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.cdc.gov/men/superbowl&quot;&gt;http://www.cdc.gov/men/superbowl&lt;/a&gt;

title: Getting to the Heart of Menopause
content: As we age, our risks for various medical issues rises. During menopause certain risks can increase for women when it comes to cardiac health and disease. As with anything else, some of its the old nature versus nurture scenario. Bad habits that you have nurtured through the years (poor diet, lack of exercise, smoking, excessive alcohol, and other known risks) can take their toll. Some families have a history or are at a heightened risk of cardiac problems. Menopause itself does not cause cardiovascular disease.Dr. Nieca Goldberg, a cardiologist and an American Heart Association volunteer restates.Menopause isnt a disease. Its a natural phase of a womans life cycle, Dr. Goldberg said. Its important for women, as they approach menopause, to really take stock of their health.Per the American Heart Association about 35,000 under the age of 50 will have a heart attack each year. Heart disease is the leading killer of women. It is suggested that there is a connection between the estrogen and the decline during menopause and the health of the heart and blood flow. Other contributing bodily changes happen during menopause which put your heart at risk:&lt;ul&gt;&lt;li&gt;Increase in blood pressure&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Bad cholesterol goes up and the good cholesterol goes down&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Certain types of fats called triglycerides in the blood increase&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ul&gt;How can women deal with the changes and protect themselves from heart disease during menopause?&lt;ul&gt;&lt;li&gt;Reduce or eliminate bad health habits.&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Eat well - fresh fruit is highly recommended&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Exercise aerobics or activities that are low resistance&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Check your hormonal levels&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ul&gt;Look at your risks on this infographic by the American Heart Association:&amp;nbsp;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.sottopelletherapy.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/heartrisk.jpg&quot;&gt;&lt;/a&gt;For more information or to take the heart health assessment at http://mylifecheck.heart.org/&amp;nbsp;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.sottopelletherapy.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/HeartHealthy.png&quot;&gt;&lt;/a&gt;Source: http://www.heart.org/HEARTORG/Conditions/More/MyHeartandStrokeNews/What-are-my-risks-for-getting-heart-disease_UCM_443757_Article.jsp

title: Don’t be a Menopause Bully
content: Have you ever been sitting at a dinner or with a group of friends and all of sudden the topic of conversation takes an uncomfortable turn? The topic is menopause and everyone starts cracking those hot flash or moody jokes, as if those feelings and experiences are funny. No one wants to be the butt of a joke. Making light of phases of life can help us get through the difficult aspects of those situations. But, when the joking is happening between couples, it can be devastating for the woman going through menopause. At a recent dinner, the jokes started and I said I went through that and it was horrible. It amazed me to see the conversation dynamically change and women started to ask questions about what to expect or relate their own experiences. It was interesting to note, the almost deafening silence of the men in the room. As if the women, had entered a space that was off limits to them.Men need to listen, acknowledge and respond to these conversations. If they dont know what to say then just to say I am not sure what to say, but I am here to listen. During menopause, women are just looking for support and reassurance that their changing bodies are not changing the way people feel about them.A woman rarely wants to hear her husband or family poke fun of her challenges with menopause. It is important for loved ones to support and acknowledge the many feelings and physical changes that are happening in a positive and encouraging manner. When menopause happens it impacts not only the woman but the entire family. Mom may be forgetful or short tempered. She may suddenly show a need for positive reinforcement for her self-esteem and body image. Ironically, many men are simultaneously experiencing a midlife crisis (which can be triggered by hormonal imbalance like andropause), which then just lends to more conflict between the couple. Suddenly, the man and the woman are changing and its important to remain consistent, faithful, and kind to each other during this time. This is not the time to say, Oh, mom is going through her changes, she is being nutty. Poking fun at the sudden weight gain and suggesting she lay off the cookies is not what she wants to hear during this time.A Womans Day article notesan increase in divorces after fifty-five due:&lt;blockquote&gt;They enter their golden years and their husband walks out the door, often for a younger woman. Thats whats happening to an increasing number of women in their fifties and sixties these days. While divorce among younger people seems to be leveling off, theres a worrisome rise in marriage breakups among the over-fifty-five crowdup 22 percent in the last decade and expected to .&lt;/blockquote&gt;Married life is challenging enough with bills, kids, and family. Add midlife bodily changes to the mix and couples are often pitted or bullying each other. Often men will isolate themselves as they are just not sure what to do or say in the midst of their wives rollercoaster or hormones. In most cases, this exactly the opposite of what women want from their husbands. The important thing to remember when going through this time is youre not alone. If you feel bullied by the jokes made or by the lack of understanding as others try to navigate the great unknown of menopause speak up. You might be surprised by the reaction when you do.&amp;nbsp; http://www.familylife.com/articles/topics/marriage/staying-married/husbands/what-wives-wish-their-husbands-knew-about-menopause#.VL1Lo3snJx0&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;

title: Spice up your sex life with BHRT!
content: Guest bloggers: &lt;a href=&quot;/?p=6762&quot;&gt;Heather P. Chauhan MD, FACOG&lt;/a&gt;, and&lt;a title=&quot;Dr. Richard Pearson&quot; href=&quot;http://www.sottopelletherapy.com/doctors/richard-pearson-md-facs/http://&quot;&gt; Richard M. Pearson MD, FACS&lt;/a&gt;EXCEED Hormone Specialists, 7512 Second Street, Germantown, Tenn. 38138 http://exceedhs.com/Whats the secret to a healthy marriage or partnership? Sex isnt everything, but intimacy and romance are an important part of any intimate relationship. Studies suggest that good sex is also good for your health since elevated endorphin and oxytocin levels lower stress, elevate mood, and prompt more cuddling with your spouse or partner.Amidst all the valentine cards and heart-shaped chocolate boxes this month, the fact remains that many couples are unhappy with their sex lives. According to the American Medical Association, 43 percent of women and 31 percent of men in the U.S. admit they have a sexual problem. But most are too embarrassed to do anything about it except reach for the Viagra.While there are various physical, emotional and lifestyle issues that can lead to sexual dysfunction, research shows that hormonal imbalances are often a primary factor.Have you noticed? The symptoms of hormone deficiency that affect relationships are the &lt;em&gt;same &lt;/em&gt;in both men and women. These often include:&lt;ul&gt;&lt;li&gt;fatigue,&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;low energy&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;low libido&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;poor sexual functioning&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;loss of motivation&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;mood swings&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ul&gt;What is happening to each of the &lt;em&gt;individuals &lt;/em&gt;is also happening to the &lt;em&gt;couple&lt;/em&gt; and amazingly they never see it. Each thinks the other has the problem!As specialists in hormone deficiency and sexual dysfunction, we initially noted this pattern in couples referred by marital, family therapy and sexual counselors. We also discovered that treating these patients and their hormone issues together as a couple is much more effective and can offer some them some hope and positive results.Testosterone is the key hormone for libido in both sexes and also generates a connection or bonding emotion between two partners. However, Low T levels have many men turning to potentially harmful forms of synthetic testosterone. Pills, patches, injections, gels and creams in generic doses can lead to hormone surges and other side effects.Bio-identical hormone replacement therapy (BHRT) pellets offer a safer, natural treatment option with precisely individualized dosing for both men and women to help restore hormones back to their proper levels.Doing BHRT together as a couple is a powerful way to help put the vitality back in your relationship. Co-treatment leads to improved compliance, earlier and better results and mutual satisfaction. With individual patients, we inquire very early about a significant other and their hormone symptoms. If possible, we then approach each individuals therapy in the context of the couples relationship.Why does this approach work? First, most couples are nearly the same age. Two-thirds of all married or cohabiting couples are within 2.5 years of each others age.Consequently, each half of the couple moves into hormonal difficulties at the same time.Women in the pre- and postmenopausal years from 40 to 60 are generally living with men of a similar age. In these men, testosterone levels are dropping and 50 percent have erectile dysfunction. Together they experience decreased hormones, loss of libido, sexual problems, moodiness and strained relationships.Second, relationships play a key role in overall health. Research shows that happy couples have a lower risk of heart disease. BHRT demonstrates benefit on heart and bone health, weight control, brain function and metabolism. Imagine the BHRT potential being magnified by the strength of the relationship!Finally, seeing ones partner make the change from poor health to optimal health, or simply associating with a healthy partner, is very powerful motivation and reinforcement. The British demonstrated this effect recently in a study of 3,700 couples attempting weight control, exercise or smoking cessation. Individuals were three times more likely to succeed if the partner joined in the challenge.The message: Fitness, vitality and BHRT all rub off on your partner.Its never too late to save your marriage or relationship! So this Valentines Day, dont turn to Viagra to spice up your sex life. Consider the natural option that BHRT offers you and your significant other for enhancing your health and revitalizing your romance so you can enjoy growing old together!&amp;nbsp;&lt;strong&gt;About Dr. Pearson and Dr. Chauhan:&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;/?p=6764&quot;&gt;http://www.sottopelletherapy.com/doctors/richard-pearson-md-facs/&lt;/a&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;/?p=6762&quot;&gt;http://www.sottopelletherapy.com/doctors/heather-pearson-chauhan-md-facog/&lt;/a&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;em&gt;&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;

title: Why Your Medical Identity is Important?
content: &lt;h2 class=&quot;post-header&quot;&gt;Guest Post : &lt;em&gt;In this LifeLock UnLocked post, our friendsat the Identity Theft Resource Center outline the risks of medical identity theft.&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/h2&gt;A lot of people make New Years resolutions to make healthier choices in the coming year. For some, that resolution also translates into making appointments for much-needed health and dental screenings, vowing to follow up on previous diagnoses, and keeping a watch on medical conditions.But while youre taking better care of your body, this is also a good time to make a resolution to take better care of your medical identity. What is a medical identity? Well, for starters, it was the leading form of data breach in 2014, largely due to the reporting laws in place that require practitioners to report leaks of patient information. Your medical identity, just like your personal identity or your financial identity, is the information that a thief can use to his own benefit while harming your ability to receive care.Medical identity theft occurs when your personally identifiable information is used by someone else for health care, health coverage, disability benefits, and more. The end result can range from mild annoyance to a life threatening conflict of care, and can also have criminal consequences for the victim if its not resolved.In August 2014, &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-birmingham-26519216&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;a woman used a stolen identity&lt;/a&gt; to give birth at a UK hospital because her three other children had already been removed from her care. Fearing that the new baby would also be taken, she used a stolen identity (of another pregnant woman) to give birth and leave the hospital with her baby. When the victim of the identity theft went to a routine appointment with her doctor, she was informed she had already given birth, jeopardizing her ability to receive prenatal and labor-delivery care.Medical identity theft can also have disastrous effects that can actually be life threatening. Imagine going to the emergency room and being given medication that youre allergic to because someone else has received care in your name and listed no known allergies. Even worse, you arrive at the hospital only to have the doctor look in your chart and see that you come in quite frequently for narcotic pain relievers, or youve previously been diagnosed with a complex physical or mental illness that interferes with your care. All because someone else is playing games with your identity and your health.Remember that medical data breaches often occur within the practitioners or hospital office in whats known as an internal data breach; an employee with access to your information can use it or sell it for someone else to use. Thats why its important to make a healthcare coverage screening part of your health maintenance. Those statements from your insurance company that arrive after a doctors visit? Dont just discard them, and not just because you need to shred them first. Read them very carefully and make sure you received the care that the statement claims you were given. But you dont have to wait for documentation to arrive, you can also check with your health coverage provider and ask for a routine look at your recent activity. If you receive any suspicious billing paperwork, follow up on it immediately in order to determine if someone is using your medical identity.&lt;em&gt;This LifeLock UnLocked post is courtesy of the &lt;a href=&quot;http://www.idtheftcenter.org/&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;Identity Theft Resource Center&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/em&gt;

title: BHRT for Parkinson’s Disease and Traumatic Brain Injury
content: BHRT or Bioidentical Hormone Replacement Therapy helps restore hormones such as testosterone, estrogen, and progesterone to their required levels. The hormones are taken from plant sources to produce molecules which are identical to the hormones our body naturally makes. BHRT is a safe and a reliable method and patients who undergo the treatment have reported feeling younger, more energetic and having decreased symptoms of menopause and andropause (male menopause) symptoms. The therapy is customized to an individuals requirements and is highly effective in both men and women. There are many benefits of BHRT which include:&lt;ul&gt;&lt;li&gt;Improved immune system&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Increased sex drive&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Balanced weight&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Improved skin condition&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Lower depression&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;A new study also suggests that it helps in Parkinson disease and traumatic brain injury&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ul&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Parkinsons disease and BHRT:&lt;/strong&gt;Parkinsons disease (PD) causes the failure and death of critical nerve cells in the brain that are called neurons. PD usually strikes the neurons in the brain area called the substantia nigra that produces dopamine. Dopamine is responsible for communicating with the part of the brain that controls movement and coordination in a human body. As PD advances, dopamine production decreases which leaves a person unable to control his movements like a normal human being. This also inhibits his ability to exercise or maintain his fitness.However, with BHRT, PD patients have reported improvement in the following areas:&lt;ul&gt;&lt;li&gt;Reduced progression of PD symptoms&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Reduced need for medicines&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;An improvement in fitness&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;An improvement in coordination&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Better mobility&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Reduction in tremors&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ul&gt;These improvements are possible with BHRT as BHRT is able to increase the production of dopamine and decrease inflammation in the female brain and testosterone in the main brain. BHRT keeps hormones in balance and revives quality of life of PD patients. Balance of hormones means a steady flow of hormones in the blood stream that helps keep PD negative symptoms in check.Also, BHRT is customized as per the needs of the individual patient. This customization to the precise needs of the patients body is the key to the success of pellet therapy. SottoPelles patent pending dosing method BioCalc allows for the treating physician to dose the pellet therapy to exactly what that patients body requires to regain balance.&lt;strong&gt;Traumatic brain injury and BHRT:&lt;/strong&gt;Research suggests that traumatic brain injury affects around 1.7 million Americans per year and it can cause cognitive, emotional as well as physical deficits. Most therapies do not provide significant improvements or recovery and the chronic symptoms continue to be a part of life of the patients forever. It has been found that brain trauma causes deficiencies in some types of hormones. When this deficiency in hormones is restored, a significant improvement is seen in patients that suffer from traumatic brain injury.BHRT are plant-based hormones that match the exact molecular structure, as well as functionality of the human hormones. Hence, BHRT bind and communicate properly to the human body receptors and hence, extend vital support to organs, tissues and cells in the human body. If prescribed properly, BHRT can benefit traumatic brain injury as well as menopause, weight gain, and even osteoporosis. Again, BHRT are customized personally and have virtually no side effects. Exact dosage needs of a patient are uncovered by a series of blood tests.BHRT needs to be researched upon even more to aid people in their illnesses and improved further to provide an even better outcome for patients suffering from PD, traumatic brain injury, etc.&amp;nbsp;If you need more information about this topic or SottoPelle Therapy, please contact us today!!&amp;nbsp;

title: A Green Diet for St. Patrick’s Day
content: Four leaf clovers, leprechauns, and green beer all are very green to commemorate St. Pattys Day, but you can be green and healthy too. One of the exciting things this St. Pattys Day is it also means spring is coming soon. The SottoPelle Team has searched for a few green recipes for you to enjoy!!! Send us your favorite healthy St. Patricks Day recipe or let us know if you enjoyed the ones listed here. Celebrate being green the healthy way. Some healthy ideas on eating:&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 30px;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Breakfast&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;Try your Smoothie Green (http://thecornerkitchenblog.com/green-smoothies/)&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt; 1 - 1 1/2 cups unsweetened almond milk, depending on how thick you like your smoothie&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt; 1 cup kale leaves, center rib removed&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt; 1 cup baby spinach&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt; 1 banana, frozen &amp;amp; cut into pieces&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt; 1 mango, peeled and cut into pieces&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt; 1 teaspoon fresh ginger&lt;/p&gt;Dr Seuss loves Green Eggs, so today is a good day to try it:&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt; 8 large eggs - beaten&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt; 1 cup chopped frozen spinach - thawed&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt; 1/2 cup low-fat milk&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt; 2 cups bread cubes or small torn pieces of bread&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt; 1/2 cup grated Swiss or Monterey jack cheese (optional)&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt; Salt and pepper to taste (optional)&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt; Read More: http://www.mrbreakfast.com/superdisplay.asp?recipeid=1204&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 30px;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Lunch&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt;&lt;em&gt;Irish Salad - Colcannon&lt;/em&gt; (http://www.goodlifeeats.com/2012/03/colcannon-with-leeks-and-kale.html)&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt;Considered to be a &quot;frugal&quot; dish - but it is healthy and tasty too.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 90px;&quot;&gt;3 - 4 medium sized russet potatoes, peeled and chopped into chunks&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 90px;&quot;&gt;8 ounces red potatoes, peeled and chopped into chunks&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 90px;&quot;&gt;10 ounces parsnips, peeled and sliced&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 90px;&quot;&gt;2 bay leaves&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 90px;&quot;&gt;5 tablespoons butter&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 90px;&quot;&gt;1 leek, cleaned and chopped&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 90px;&quot;&gt;4 ounces kale, chopped&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 90px;&quot;&gt;1 - 1 1/2 cup whole milk&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 90px;&quot;&gt;1 teaspoon salt, or to taste&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 90px;&quot;&gt;1/4 teaspoon black pepper, or to taste&lt;/p&gt; &lt;em&gt;Green Tomatoes and Mozzarella -&lt;/em&gt; Make your typical Caprese Salad green by replacing red tomatoes with green ones. (http://www.kalynskitchen.com/2010/08/recipe-for-green-goddess-tomato.html)&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt;8 slices fresh tomato (make all slices about the same diameter, I used Green Zebra tomatoes)&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt;4 slices fresh mozzarella&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt;3-4 T Green Goddess Salad Dressing&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 30px;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Pub Snacks&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 30px;&quot;&gt;What is St. Pattys Day without some Pub food?&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 30px;&quot;&gt;(http://kblog.lunchboxbunch.com/2013/03/lucky-leprechaun-dip-creamy-green.html)&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 30px;&quot;&gt;Feel Lucky with &lt;em&gt;Green Leprechaun Dip&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt;1 can white cannellini beans (1 1/2 cups) - drain/rinse in hot water&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt;1 cup kale (I actually used frozen kale! But fresh works too)&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt;4 Tbsp. extra virgin olive oil&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt;2 Tbsp. apple cider vinegar&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt;2 tsp lemon juice + generous pinch of lemon zest&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt;1/2 tsp fine black pepper&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt;3 dashes of cayenne&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt;1/4 cup raw cashews (no need to soak if using a high speed blender or food processor)&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt;1 1/2 Tbsp. tahini, roasted, organic&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt;1/4+ cup warm water&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt;1/4 cup chopped parsley, flat-leaf&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt;Optional: garlic powder or roasted garlic&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 30px;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Dinner&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 30px;&quot;&gt;&lt;em&gt;Green Pizza&lt;/em&gt; (See recipe http://www.eatingwell.com/recipes/arugula_broccoli_pesto_pizza.html)&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt; 1 pound prepared pizza dough, preferably whole-wheat&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt; 2 cups chopped broccoli florets&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt; 1/4 cup water&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt; 5 ounces arugula, any tough stems removed, chopped (about 6 cups)&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt; Pinch of salt&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt; Freshly ground pepper to taste&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt; 1/2 cup prepared pesto&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt; 1 cup shredded part-skim mozzarella cheese&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 30px;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Dessert&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt;Ice Cream can be healthy and green too. This creative Greek yogurt recipe combines health, green, and ice cream for an amazing dessert.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt;&lt;em&gt;Mint Chocolate Chip Greek Yogurt Ice Cream&lt;/em&gt; (See: http://immaeatthat.com/2013/01/07/chobani-recipes-mint-chocolate-chip-ice-cream/)&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt;2 frozen bananas&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt;3/4 cup almond milk, original&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt;2 cups spinach, packed&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt;1 container (16 ounces) Chobani Vanilla Chocolate Chunk Greek Yogurt&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt;1/4 tsp mint extract&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt;3 Tbsp. dark chocolate chips, roughly chopped&lt;/p&gt; &lt;strong&gt;Green Beer&lt;/strong&gt; has lots of carbs, and you feel like having a healthy spirit? We found this interesting twist on green alcoholic drink. (See http://www.telegraph.co.uk/foodanddrink/healthy-recipes/10909277/Healthy-green-juice-with-an-alcoholic-twist.html) 50ml fresh green juice (I use 1 cucumber, 3 apples, 4 large curly kale leaves, 2 pears) 25ml sugar syrup or elderflower cordial 25ml fresh lime juice 50ml vodka&lt;p style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;So be healthy, eat and drink in moderation and BE GREEN this St. Patricks Day!!&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;em&gt;***If youre allergic to any ingredients noted then omit from recipe or replace with suitable item.&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;em&gt;Additional Link: http://greatist.com/health/healthy-green-recipes-st-patricks-day&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/p&gt;

title: PMS and Men
content: Mother Nature and Father Time dont play favorites when it comes to men and PMS and mid-life changes.Life is change as is aging. Everyone hears about womens horror stories about going through menopause or when its that &quot;time of the month.&quot; Men often attribute their significant others bad moods or perceived negative reactions as its their hormones again. But, as it turns out Men have PMS too.An entertaining article from Cosmo gives a great take on men and their moods during mid-life.&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 30px;&quot;&gt;Of course, men dont actually have the lovely bonafide PMS related to preparing the uterus and egg for fertilization. But some go through whats called the male PMS: &quot;IMS&quot; (Irritable Male Syndrome). This can be attributed to men experiencing a drop in testosterone, the hormone that gives them their mojo. Their IMS can happen at any time, as testosterone levels fluctuate during the day, but they tend to be highest during the morning and drop as the day goes on.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 30px;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;What happens when a dude experiences IMS?&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt;It can cause him to be more angry, and moody. Guys who do have IMS can also be super anxious, depressed, and exhibit lower self-esteem.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 30px;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;What should you do when hes male PMS-ing?&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt;Talk to your man if his moodiness becomes an issue and raise your concerns with your doctor as well. Your doc could prescribe anything from a change in diet, stress relief advice, hormone creams/medication, or other remedies/medications if necessary. If your guy is being a total beotch and you think he might be on his &quot;period&quot; or experiencing some IMS, cut him some slack. We do it too around that time of the month. &lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 30px;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Now, how about &quot;Manopause&quot; - is that a thing too?&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt;Yes, and its called andropause and is the age related hormonal changes that happen to men. Typically, we all have peaks and valleys in testosterone levels. The level in each person, specifically men will vary on the individual. As men age, some experience a drop in testosterone.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 30px;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Do men have the same symptoms as women when they are andropausal?&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;ul style=&quot;padding-left: 30px;&quot;&gt;&lt;ul&gt;&lt;li&gt;Changes in Sleep - Sleep changes can be caused by many health or emotional issues. Stress is large cause of loss of sleep or disturbances in normal sleep patterns. If there is an ongoing sleep disturbance without any obvious cause, it may be due to andropause.&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Libido and sex related concerns or symptoms.&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Physical changes, sudden weight gain, loss of body hair, decrease in bone density (yes men are at risk here too), and less energy.&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ul&gt;&lt;/ul&gt;&lt;ul style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt;&lt;li&gt;Emotional and mental changes that cause concern and could be related to male menopause are lack of focus or mental clarity, feeling sad without cause, and general lack of interest in activities or motivation.&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ul&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 30px;&quot;&gt;There are other medical conditions that can impact testosterone levels and cause these symptoms, so if you or your partner are experiencing any of these symptoms it is wise to consult your doctor.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 30px;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;How do I find out if this happening to me?&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt;A blood test is the only way to determine testosterone loss or a reduction in the bio availability of it.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 30px;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Can I raise my testosterone by myself? &lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt;No, often when your testosterone levels are lower than normal for you, there is some cause for it. This is why its important to speak candidly with your physician so he can determine the reason and treat it and address your symptoms appropriately. SottoPelle offers Pellet Therapy to men who are experiencing low testosterone or related hormonal balance. The doctor will do a blood test, and make sure your Low T is due to normal aging, and does not have any other underlying health conditions causing the symptoms. Once you get a green light from labs, you can then start Pellet Therapy which will eliminate most of the symptoms you are experiencing by balancing out your system.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 30px;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;What can I do?&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 60px;&quot;&gt;See a doctor, address the issues, and take action. Keep or get into healthy lifestyle habits. Exercise and diet contribute positively to overall health regime, so it will help your body as a whole.&lt;/p&gt;&lt;p style=&quot;padding-left: 30px;&quot;&gt;&lt;em&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Remember Mother Nature does not take sides on body changes and aging - men and women are in it together!!&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/p&gt; http://www.cosmopolitan.com/health-fitness/advice/a4350/do-guys-have-periods/

As men age, some experience a drop in testosterone.&lt;strong&gt;Do men have the same symptoms as women when they are andropausal?&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;ul&gt;&lt;li&gt;Changes in Sleep - Sleep changes can be caused by many health or emotional issues. Stress is large cause of loss of sleep or disturbances in normal sleep patterns. If there is an ongoing sleep disturbance without any obvious cause, it may be due to andropause.&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Libido and sex related concerns or symptoms.&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;Physical changes, sudden weight gain, loss of body hair, decrease in bone density (yes men are at risk here too), and less energy.&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ul&gt;&lt;ul&gt;&lt;li&gt;Emotional and mental changes that cause concern and could be related to male menopause are lack of focus or mental clarity, feeling sad without cause, and general lack of interest in activities or motivation.&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ul&gt;There are other medical conditions that can impact testosterone levels and cause these symptoms, so if you or your partner are experiencing any of these symptoms it is wise to consult your doctor.&lt;strong&gt;How do I find out if this happening to me?&lt;/strong&gt;A blood test is the only way to determine testosterone loss or a reduction in the bio availability of it.&lt;strong&gt;Can I raise my testosterone by myself? &lt;/strong&gt;No, often when your testosterone levels are lower than normal for you, there is some cause for it. This is why its important to speak candidly with your physician so he can determine the reason and treat it and address your symptoms appropriately. SottoPelle offers Pellet Therapy to men who are experiencing low testosterone or related hormonal balance. The doctor will do a blood test, and make sure your Low T is due to normal aging, and does not have any other underlying health conditions causing the symptoms. Once you get a green light from labs, you can then start Pellet Therapy which will eliminate most of the symptoms you are experiencing by balancing out your system.&lt;strong&gt;What can I do?&lt;/strong&gt;See a doctor, address the issues, and take action. Keep or get into healthy lifestyle habits. Exercise and diet contribute positively to overall health regime, so it will help your body as a whole.Remember Mother Nature does not take sides on body changes and aging - men and women are in it together!!&amp;nbsp; http://www.cosmopolitan.com/health-fitness/advice/a4350/do-guys-have-periods/

title: Winter Cold and Aging
content: This has been one of the worst winters experienced around the country. Everyone is feeling the chill including the normally warmer Snow Bird states. We know that extreme cold can impact the elderly and children, but how does it impact those in middle age or going through Menopause?&lt;h2&gt;Menopause&lt;/h2&gt;Everyone has heard about Hot Flashes during Menopause, but many women experience Cold Flashes. This A cold flash, often called the chills, is a sudden feeling of intense cold, usually accompanied with shivering. The difference between cold and shivering as a reaction to weather as opposed to a medical condition is the unexpected situation in which it happens. The brain monitors and regulates the bodys temperature, according to the University of Illinois Medical Center, and when something throws it off balance, such as menopause, chemicals will travel through the bloodstream, causing the brain to raise the normal temperature set point. This causes you to feel cold and shiver to help your bodys temperature rise to meet the new set point. Due to estrogen levels decreasing, hormonal and biochemical imbalances occur, according to the 34 Menopause Symptoms website. The falling estrogen levels are thought to be the cause of both hot and cold flashes. The hypothalamus, the area of the brain responsible for body temperature regulation, becomes overactive. This causes the hypothalamus to release chemicals that cause blood vessels in the skin to expand in order for heat to be emitted. The end result is a cold flash.During Perimenopause many women will experience cold intolerance. Often patients will complain that their hands, nose, and feet are very cold. Cold extremities can be caused by hormonal imbalance and will result in heightened discomfort during periods of extremely cold weather.It is important to avoid potential triggers of cold flashes by drinking warm drinks, take hot baths, wear sweaters or just try to maintain an even temperature in your residence. Keeping feet and hands warm can often help warm the rest of the body. Have warm slippers available that you can easily slip into and out of as your body temperature fluctuates. If the episodes become too disruptive, please contact your physician or our team for assistance on managing these symptoms.&lt;h2&gt;Exercise&lt;/h2&gt;During cold weather it is often hard to exercise due to lack of motivation or environment. It is important to exercise and keep in shape. The cold weather will inhibit anyones desire to leave the warmth of their heated home or even get out from under the covers to hit the gym. Proper diet and exercise are critical for staying healthy at any age especially during cold weather. People tend to get ill more often during cold periods of time due to many factors. Lack of exercise, inhalation of cold air versus warm air, and poor diet (aka Comfort Food), are some of the reasons why many get sicker during the colder months.&lt;h2&gt;Diet&lt;/h2&gt;Some great suggestions from EveryDayHealth.com for winter super-foods for menopause are:&lt;h3&gt;Legumes&lt;/h3&gt;Some of the more bothersome symptoms associated with menopause result from a state of estrogen deficiency, says Erica Matluck, ND, a naturopath at One Medical Group in San Francisco.A diet rich in phytoestrogens can help with this, and soybeans, chickpeas, and lentils are some of the most potent sources. Legumes are also rich in folic acid, magnesium, potassium, B vitamins, and fiber, and are 20 to 25 percent protein, making them a true superfood. Matluck recommends including phytoestrogens in every meal.&lt;h3&gt;Flaxseed&lt;/h3&gt;Flaxseeds high concentration of essential fatty acids (omega-3 and omega-6) can relieve inflammation, fluid retention, depression, and irritability, says Karyn Duggan, a certified nutrition consultant at One Medical Group.This little super-food with a nutty flavor is also a rich source of plant lignans. Those can modulate the metabolism and use of estrogen, and are therefore helpful for minimizing menopausal symptoms like hot flashes, sweating, and vaginal dryness, she says. Flaxseed can be purchased ground or whole and added to dishes like oatmeal and smoothies.&lt;h3&gt;Green Leafy Vegetables&lt;/h3&gt;Fill your plate with cruciferous vegetables like kale, collards, or other leafy greens. These greens are good sources of calcium and magnesium, both of which are beneficial for bone health, says Denise Londergan, RD, LD, an integrative dietitian/nutritionist at Ohio State Universitys Wexner Medical Center in Columbus.Magnesium-rich foods can also help with migraines, depression, and anxiety, reports the Office of Dietary Supplements at the National Institutes of Health.&lt;h3&gt;Cold-Water Fish&lt;/h3&gt;Fish that thrive in cold waters salmon, mackerel, sardines, and herring, for instance are excellent sources of omega-3 fatty acids, which help relieve hot flashes and symptoms of depression in women over 40, according to a study published in the journal Menopause in 2011. Omega-3s also help protect against heart disease, according to the National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute an increasing concern for women as they reach menopause. Federal dietary guidelines for Americans recommend incorporating a serving of fish into meals at least two times each week.These are just a few suggestion, there are others listed on this site and others. Eating well sometimes is not enough to offset discomfort during the cold weather. If you are experiencing discomfort from severe cold weather, contact your physician or the SottoPelle team for assistance.Bundle up, stay warm, and spring is almost here!!&lt;em&gt;Sources:&lt;/em&gt; http://www.livestrong.com/article/283423-menopause-cold-flashes/ http://menopause-aid.blogspot.com/2011/03/cold-flashes-chills-during-menopause.html http://www.everydayhealth.com/pictures/winter-superfoods-menopause-symptoms/#02
